title: oscars members must proved have watched every film big stars
story: Oscar winners should be decided only by Academy members who have seen all long-listed films, it has been suggested, amid deep resentment at the “snobby” institution rejecting actors whose “brand” they don’t value.Sunday's Academy Awards have been overshadowed by controversy once again, after Jennifer Lopez was ignored for her role in Hustlers, and Adam Sandler snubbed for Uncut Gems.The rejection of their work was put partly down to snobbery, and partly down to Academy members not bothering to watch the films.“First of all, Hustlers is not an ‘Oscar movie,’” one Academy member said.“It’s a little too rough around the edges, and I’m assuming some other people in the acting category didn’t see it.“Actors tend to think of Jennifer Lopez as a phenomenon more than an actress, per se. Lady Gaga lost the Oscar to Olivia Colman — a real actor’s actor.”The voter added that an actor’s reputation in Hollywood circles can decide a category more than their actual performance, and that many Academy members will not watch all the films up for nomination.He told the New York Post: “Unfortunately, actors become brands. Sandler’s brand doesn’t scream Oscar, but Leo DiCaprio’s and Jonathan Pryce’s do.”Carey Mulligan agreed, and argued that the 8,000 members of the Academy should have to prove that they had seen the films in their category. Each member is allowed to vote in their section – be it acting, make up, editing and so on.Unlike the Tony Awards, for Broadway shows, there is no requirement to prove you have seen the films you are deciding between.Mulligan, nominated for an Oscar in 2010 for An Education, said that forcing all voting members to watch the films would mean more recognition for female directors.“I don’t think you can watch those films and not think they deserve recognition,” she said. “I think they need to be watched. Maybe you shouldn’t be allowed to vote unless you can prove you’ve seen every single one. There should be a test. The films that did get left out are indisputably brilliant.”No women were nominated for best director, and only one non-white person received recognition for acting.Author Stephen King sided with Mulligan, writing about concerns of bias among Academy members, who may choose not to see certain films they were asked to decide upon.“Here’s another piece of the puzzle. Voters are supposed to look at all films in serious contention. This year, that would be about 60,” he wrote in The Washington Post. “There’s no way of checking how many voters actually do, because viewing is on the honour system.“How many of the older, whiter contingent actually saw Harriet, about Harriet Tubman, or The Last Black Man in San Francisco? Just asking the question. If they did see all the films, were they moved by what they saw? Did they feel the catharsis that’s the basis of all that artists aspire to? Did they understand?”Amy Pascal, producer of Little Women, noted that twice as many women than men attended early screenings of the film, suggesting that male voters were skipping it.Voters think that these kinds of stories are important to me, and these kinds of stories are less important to me,” she said.The situation is not new. In 92 years, only five women have been nominated for best director, and only one has ever won – Kathryn Bigelow, in 2010, with The Hurt Locker.Yet is it causing increasing concern, as the 2015 “Oscars So White” campaign and the #MeToo movement born out of Harvey Weinstein’s 2016 downfall fade in the memory, seemingly having had little impact.The failure to nominate women is not a reflection of their commercial clout.Women made up 10.6 per cent of the directors of the top 100 grossing movies from 2019, according to the University of Southern California’s Annenberg Inclusion Initiative - the highest since the institute began tracking the data in 2007.Israeli-American director Alma Har’el, whose film Honey Boy was highly acclaimed on the festival circuit, suggested creating two director awards, in male and female categories.The status quo will always protect itself by getting women and underrepresented filmmakers to play a game they can’t win - by making us believe that anything other than breaking into the white boys’ club is failure,” she said.She said a new category would “build a new world that celebrates us.”Industry activists are taking matters into their own hands.Give Her a Break, a charity, has launched an online portal to the Oscars live stream that will flip during the ad breaks to showcase female-directed films. It will then switch back to the Oscars when the awards show resumes.“They stole our Oscars. So we stole their ads,” the campaign promotion reads.Gerwig, whose boyfriend Noah Baumbach is nominated for best director for Marriage Story, remains sanguine about the situation.“I think that the directors branch could probably stand to bolster its lady numbers,” she said.“This will go to the top of my to-do list!”More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: wuhan evacuees arrive uk two week isolation two britons test
story: Around 200 evacuees will remain in complete isolation for two weeks in Milton Keynes after the second and final flight from the Chinese city of Wuhan landed in the UK.Passengers were taken to the Kents Hill Park hotel and conference centre in the Bedfordshire town, where, unlike the first tranche of evacuees, they will not be allowed to socialise in a bid to reduce the chance of a coronavirus outbreak.Two Britons who had expected to board the flight in China were prevented from doing so following last-minute medical checksOne told Sky News: “Now we are stranded in Wuhan having missed the last plane out of Wuhan and our last means of evacuation.”It came as two more Britons were diagnosed with the illness yesterday, both of whom contracted it in the French Alps via a British “super spreader”.One man tested positive after returning to his home near Palma, Majorca, while the other had returned to the UK and is being treated at the Royal Free hospital in north west London.As the worldwide death toll continued to rise, members of the public appealed for information about the movements of those who may have unwittingly passed on the virus.Richard Tedder, visiting professor in medical virology at Imperial College London, warned of the “potential risk of a pandemic”.“The concern is the potential for the silent transmissions to go unrecognised until they are brought into the open by people developing illness from onward transmission,” he said.Prof Tedder noted an “uncomfortable similarity” with the emergence of HIV in the 1980s due to its ability to be transmitted by people showing no symptoms and called for diagnostic testing for antibodies.“Without that we are truly flying blind if it is the case that the coronavirus can be transmitted by those without symptoms,” he added.Dominic Raab, the Foreign Secretary, said the repatriation flight from Wuhan had brought back 105 British nationals and family members, as well as 95 European nationals and family members.One of the two Brits remaining in Wuhan says he was denied access to the last Government-chartered flight back to the UK after failing a temperature check because he was wearing two jackets.Josh Skarratts said he had worn a hoodie and a jacket to try and comply with hand luggage weight requirements and in preparation for cold weather in the UK.But when his temperature was taken from underneath his armpits, the reading of 37.5C (99.5F) was deemed too high by officials in the Chinese city.The comedy club owner said another Briton was turned away for the same reason.Now we are stranded in Wuhan having missed the last plane out of Wuhan and our last means of evacuation, he told Sky News.It's quite a difficult pill to swallow when you know the exact reason why you weren't allowed on the plane could have been avoided.Mr Skarratts added that he is confident the Foreign Office and the British Embassy will help him and the other Briton to leave Wuhan.The evacuees are believed to have only hand luggage with them. The NHS is providing welcome packs with toiletries and basic clothing. Yesterday, staff were seen carrying armfuls of clothes from Primark into the Milton Keynes conference centre.Couples and families were allocated two rooms each and were given access to Netflix, magazines, books, baby equipment including highchairs, children's toys and games, mobile phones, and tablets for reading, games, and internet.Health officials were concerned about catering arrangements and suggested delivering meals to people's rooms instead of having a communal facility. A source close to South Central Ambulance Service said patients would be confined to their rooms. Milton Keynes Council said local schools had been alerted and were working to “update and reassure parents.The first group of Britons who returned on a flight last month are continuing their quarantine at Arrowe Park Hospital, Merseyside.Meanwhile, in France, the five Britons diagnosed with coronavirus were being monitored at a hospital in Grenoble.They include Bob Saynor, 48 and his nine-year-old son as well as three members of a party of seven adults who regularly stayed with the family at their chalet in the Alpine resort area of Contamines-Montjoie near Mont Blanc.Mr Saynor’s mother, Jean, told the  he was doing “fine” and that she understood no-one was “seriously ill”.All five had come into contact with a middle-aged businessman from Brighton who had contracted the virus in Singapore.Last night, health authorities arranged an emergency public meeting in the neighbouring town of Saint Gervais, to quell any anguish in the area. “Don’t panic. There is no reason to worry about local life. You cannot catch it on the street. You cannot catch it on the pistes,” said one official. More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: garden sustainable space how to build tips tricks climate 20 pledges
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.This year, Chris Riotta is growing his own fruit and vegetables – in the middle of New York CityWhether you’re working with a few feet of space in a community vegetable patch, or have 65 acres of luscious foliage on a sprawling estate (looking at you, Oprah Winfrey), the first step to building a sustainable garden is mapping out a vision of your intentions.Each year before planting my own vegetable patch, I draw out an image of the garden I hope to build, indicating where each plant should go based on available sunlight and shading.&nbspI’m currently planning to build the largest garden I’ve ever grown, while working to harvest one-third of my annual vegetable consumption directly from my backyard, as part of my mission for The Independent’s 20&nbspPledges&nbspfor 2020 initiative. While mapping out the garden, I put together a few tips and tricks to help get you started on your own sustainable vegetable patch.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesPlan out where to place your&nbspplantsRoot to fruit: How to join the ethical food revolutionI like to plant crops that grow on vines (think: cucumbers and cherry tomatoes) in small groups, as close to a fence as possible so they scale upwards, while giving other plants that will likely grow much larger a separate space off to the side. That way, I can still walk by and tend to the crops growing up the fence, no matter how big the other plants off to the side eventually grow.&nbspThis also works with smaller plots of soil like community garden space: keep clusters of similar plants in the same tight groups, and don’t worry so much about spacing. With some proper TLC, plants usually find their way around each other in the dirt.&nbspSeeds can always begin growing indoors ahead of the season around the time you lay out your soil, which will provide you with plenty of time to start growing your crops in a stable environment. Some farmers will recommend you transport these seeds to your garden based on the location of the moon, but since I don’t have time for all that, I simply give the soil a good rinse of water for a week before transporting or planting anything in my garden.Study your plotBefore stepping into that dirt, it’s important to study your space and gain an understanding of how many hours of sunlight you’re working with and what kind of plants grow well in the region. Most will require about eight hours of sun, but if you’re in a shaded area and can only get six, that should still work, as many plants favour partial shade and only require about four hours of direct sunlight.&nbspGetting a head start on laying out the groundwork for your garden will help it produce sustainable harvests that last throughout the summer months – and then some. You can look up the last frost date in your region here.&nbspI tend to lay out my organic soil exactly where I plant to grow my garden about six weeks before this date.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Back to our roots: Warming winter vegetables recipes Show all 2Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Maximise your spaceIt’s also just as important to consider ways to maximise the space while gardening. Vertical garden walls can be purchased or made easily in DIY projects, allowing plants to grow above each other rather than spread out over a small space.&nbspOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailLastly, don’t be afraid to plant intensively. Most crops only need a few inches of space for their roots to grow: things like peppers, tomatoes, broccoli and kale can all grow much closer together than most people think. I tend to believe that crops grow better when they’re in close, clustered mixes of similar plants, but that’s just my unprofessional semi-gardening enthusiast opinion.Transplant the seeds to your garden once its warm enough for them to survive in an outdoor climate, but only when the seeds are busting out of their trays or starter pots. The seeds should look vibrant and almost too big for their trays by the time they are brought to the garden for planting.&nbspI tend to believe the first moments catering to a garden and each inidual plant are some of the most important in a life cycle the only way a garden will produce healthy crops is with tender love and care during its birth. title: instagram update new feature likes feed follow
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Feature intended to let people clear up their feedsInstagram has added a new feature to let you find out who you don't like.The tool is intended to allow users to clean up their news feeds by unfollowing accounts they don't interact with or want to see less of.It comes alongside another tool that lets people see who they hear from most, which is also supposed to help people curate their feeds.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe tool can be found by heading to your own profile and clicking the following button. From there, you'll see the normal list of everyone you follow, but also the new update.There is an option for looking at the Instagram accounts that appear most in your feed. Those are also likely to be the ones you interact with most, given that Instagram prizes things like likes when deciding what to show, but could also be annoying accounts that post too much.The other option shows users who they interact with least. That can include dozens of people that might be worth unfollowing if their feed or stories are becoming overwhelming.The new feature was found in testing late last year, but has finally rolled out to everyone with a new update and announcement from Instagram.It comes after the app also added the option to see the people you follow sorted by how recently you started doing so. That is similarly intended to allow people to better understand their feed, and get rid of anyone they followed a long time ago but no longer wish to see posts from.Selena Gomez says Instagram is ‘destroying’ some of her generationAll of the features are intended to allow people to have more control of their news feed and hopefully better curate what they want to see.“Instagram is really about bringing you closer to the people and things you care about — but we know that over time, your interests and relationships can evolve and change,” a spokesperson said.“Whether you graduate, move to a new city, or become obsessed with a new interest and find a community, we want to make it easier to manage the accounts you follow on Instagram so that they best represent your current connections and interests.”Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: bbc one down storm ciara not working uk weather latest
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The broadcaster's flagship channel struggles&nbspamid destructive weather: 'Causing us some problems'BBC One went off-air for more than seven minutes on Sunday morning due to interference by Storm Ciara.&nbspThe BBC's flagship channel, which at the time was broadcasting Nicky Campbell's&nbspThe Big Questions, began to glitch at 11.02am before dropping off completely a minute later.&nbspThis is BBC One, I'm sorry but due to technical problems we've lost contact with The Big Questions studio in Salford, an announcer said shortly afterwards.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesInstead of moving images, the broadcast played&nbspsmooth jazz music alongside a message which read: We are sorry for the break in this programme and are trying to correct the fault.She later added: It seems that the stormy conditions up in Salford are causing us some problems. We are working as hard as we can against the weather to get back to Big Questions and Nicky in Salford as quickly&nbspas we can.At 11.08am, the announcer said the channel had solved the issue and thanked&nbspviewers for bearing with us, resulting in&nbspa failed attempt to return the broadcast to TV screens.Unfortunately we're not able to go back to Big Questions in Salford,&nbspbut please do bear with us one second, while we figure out what we're gonna do this morning, she then apologised.It was not until 11.10am that footage returned as normal.&nbspThe unusual interruption came amid travel chaos inflicted by Ciara, which is the worst storm to strike&nbspBritain in seven years.&nbspTrains, flights and ferries have been cancelled and severe weather warnings issued as&nbspCiara was forecast to pummel the UK with winds of up to 80mph.Created with Sketch. They were to be the last pieces of the lunar surface to come back to Earth, since humanity has not been back in the nearly 50 years since.That means that those remaining samples are especially precious since they are limited and can not be easily replaced. They can also be profoundly illuminating, offering us our only chance to get close to rock taken from a whole separate world.Created with Sketch.Nasa's groundbreaking decade of space exploration: In pictures Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Mystic Mountain, a pillar of gas and dust standing at three-light-years tall, bursting with jets of gas flom fledgling stars buried within, was captured by Nasa's Hubble Space Telelscope in February 2010The first ever selfie taken on an alien planet, captured by Nasa's Curiosity Rover in the early days of its mission to explore Mars in 2012Death of a star: This image from Nasa's Chandra X-ray telescope shows the supernova of Tycho, a star in our Milky Way galaxyArrokoth, the most distant object ever explored, pictured here on 1 January 2019 by a camera on Nasa's New Horizons spaceraft at a distance of 4.1 billion miles from EarthAn image of the Large Magellanic Cloud galaxy seen in infrared light by the Herschel Space Observatory in January 2012. It has since been suggested that they may instead be formed by flowing sand NasaJPLUniversity of ArizonaMorning Aurora: Nasa astronaut Scott Kelly captured this photograph of the green lights of the aurora from the International Space Station in October 2015Now researchers have found a new approach that could make the most of those limited samples as well as shedding new light on what they mean, by taking only a single piece of dust.We're&nbspanalyzing&nbsprocks from space, atom by atom, said&nbspJennika&nbspGreer, the paper's first author and a&nbspPhD&nbspstudent at the Field Museum and University of Chicago.  It's the first time a lunar sample has been studied like this. We're using a technique many geologists haven't even heard of.Scientists to make air out of lunar dust amid plans to live on MoonAs researchers make use of the new technique, they expect to find a vast set of new information about the lunar surface.We can apply this technique to samples no one has studied, Philipp Heck, a curator at the Field Museum, associate professor at the University of Chicago, and co-author of the paper, adds. You're almost guaranteed to find something new or unexpected.This technique has such high sensitivity and resolution, you find things you wouldn't find otherwise and only use up a small bit of the sample.The technique is called atom probe tomography, and involves incredibly precise manipulation of inidual grains. It has previously been used in industrial processes – but the new breakthrough has come in turning it for the first time to lunar samples.It works something like nanocarpentry, said Professor Heck: like a carpenter shapes wood, we do it at the nanoscale to minerals.The sample is placed inside a special probe and then shot with a laser that knocks off inidual atoms, which then fall onto a special plate. Researchers can examine those elements by timing how long they take to hit the detector – since heavier ones take longer – and so the type of atom can be worked out.It has already helped researchers see the weathering and materials that can be found inside the lunar soil. That in turn could help future astronauts as they move to live on the Moon, since they could survive by taking resources out of that dust.The researchers now hope they can get hold of samples from elsewhere on the Moon, and elsewhere in space, to allow them to better understand the makeup of the worlds that surround us. They compare our current understanding to analysing Earth using only one mountain range – to get a fuller grasp, they will need to examine a variety of terrains across the solar system.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium....and the films that beat themIt’s easy to get caught up in&nbspawards season&nbspexcitement as the Oscars approach – the glitz and glamour of the red carpet generating global talking points, memes and pub chatter for weeks on end.But when it’s really broken down, the Oscars are essentially just a microcosm of Hollywood. It’s a depressing fact that films directed by previous winners have more chance of being nominated than those directed by newcomers.Because of this, the&nbspbest film in any given year almost never wins the evening’s most coveted prize – in fact, it’s sometimes&nbspnot even&nbspnominated in the first place.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesOver the decades, there have been countless glaring omissions&nbsp– films that were nominated but were beaten by far inferior films&nbspand classic films&nbspthat failed to secure a single nomination.As the 2020 Oscars approach – a ceremony that’s fast becoming a two-horse race between a film that actually deserves the top prize (Parasite) and a film that does not (1917) – we’ve run through 20 brilliant films that you would have expected to be a&nbspBest Picture winner, but weren’t.Click through the bellow gallery to see what films made the listCreated with Sketch.Oscars: 21 great films that never won Best Picture Show all 23Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Long revered as one of the greatest films ever made, Orson Welles' debut – a film following newspaper tycoon Charles Foster Kane – was just another nominee back in the day, losing out to How Green Was My Valley. The Searchers may be considered John Ford's greatest film, but it was not treated as such back in the 1950s. In fact, the western starring John Wayne failed to earn a single nomination. Around the World in 80 Days turned out to be more the Academy's cup of tea.Not only did Alfred Hitchcock never win an Oscar (save for his memorial award in 1968), but neither did any of his films – one of which is Vertigo, a classic that won Sight &amp Sound's once-a-decade greatest films of all time poll in 2012. If it had been nominated, it would have faced stiff competition in the form of eventual winner All About Eve.One of the films that kickstarted the New Hollywood Cinema era, The Graduate may have won director Mike Nichols an Oscar, but it ultimately lost out to Norman Jewison's In the Heat of the Night.  Stanley Kubrick's sci-fi classic remains one of the most influential pieces of cinema there is. The Academy didn't agree. The Academy nominated Kubrick for Best Director and awarded the visual effects in favour of considering 2001 for Best Picture (it didn't even get nominated). That year's winner was Oliver!, the musical by Carol Reed.Despite Taxi Driver's failure to win the main award, its nomination in four categories showed the Academy had good intentions. That All the President's Men and Network also lost out to eventual winner Rocky shows that, ultimately, it never really stood a chance.Francis Ford Coppola's ambitious Vietnam War epic Apocalypse Now received a grand total of eight nominations, but only went home with two prizes (for cinematography and sound) losing out to drama Kramer vs. Kramer.Of all the Oscar blows dealt to Martin Scorsese over the decades, none landed harder than Raging Bull losing out to Robert Redford's weepie Ordinary People, an oversight many consider one of the Academy's most egregious.  Another sci-fi classic overlooked by the Oscars was Blade Runner, which didn't even get nominated in the Best Picture category (Gandhi ended up winning). Ridley Scott's The Martian went on to receive seven nominations in 2017 – evidence, perhaps, of the Academy taking responsibility for its past errors.1023 Do the Right Thing (1989)Spike Lee's Do the Right Thing failing to win Best Picture at the 1990 Oscars is one thing – losing out to Driving Miss Daisy is another thing altogether.   Having awarded both The Godfather Part I and The Godfather Part II Best Picture in 1972 and 1974 respectively, the Academy seemed destined to appreciate Martin Scorsese's Goodfellas. But no – Kevin Costner's directorial debut Dances with Wolves was the most appealing choice for voters.New talent on the block Quentin Tarantino's second feature Pulp Fiction won him the coveted Palme d'Or at Cannes in 1994 – a success he failed to match back on home turf. While he won an Original Screenplay Oscar, his film was beaten by Forrest Gump......and it wasn't the only one. Frank Darabont's adaptation of Stephen King's prison-set novella The Shawshank Redemption also fell victim to Robert Zemeckis' Oscar-friendly Forrest Gump. We don't see that film sitting atop the IMDb top 250 though, do we?If Heat was released today, there's no way it wouldn't be a Best Picture frontrunner. That it was completely ignored in favour of Braveheart is a huge travesty.You may think it was remiss of the Academy to shun Fargo, but it did come pretty close to winning, its chances bolstered somewhat by seven nominations and two wins (Actress for Frances McDormand and Original Screenplay for the Coen Brothers). It lost out to The English Patient.Having won Best Director five years previous for Schindler's List, Steven Spielberg was strongly expected to take home the top prizes for his Second World War epic. Cue Shakespeare In Love upsetting everybody.David Fincher's Facebook drama got shunned in favour of British patriotism in an Oscar two-horse race for the ages that ultimately saw The King's Speech crowned winner.1823 We Need to Talk About Kevin (2011)Lynne Ramsay has directed two films that would have been deserving of Best Picture: You Were Never Really Here and this, We Need to Talk About Kevin. It's easy to see why Hollywood was temporarily more charmed by The Artist, but it's clear which film will stand the test of time.It's almost unthinkable to recall that the Coen brothers' Inside Llewyn Davis only scored two Oscar nominations in the cinematography and sound mixing categories, respectively. In the ensuing years, the film has been hailed as one of the greatest of the 2010s, meaning that its no-show at the Oscars will go down as one of the Academy's biggest omissions. Still, it would have had a hard time winning over 12 Years a Slave.For the 2015 Oscars race, you were either team Birdman or team Boyhood. Richard Linklater's labour of love, shot intermittently over 12 years, ultimately failed to win. If there's any justice, Andrea Arnold will one day become an Oscar winner, but in a perfect world, she would have already won for American Honey, a drama deserving of Best Picture if there ever was one.Horror rarely gets recognised at the Oscars, but Get Out is the closest the genre had come in years. Jordan Peele may have taken home the Best Original Screenplay award, but the stars aligned for Guillermo del Toro's fantasy The Shape of Water instead.Roma was strongly expected to become the first ever foreign language film to win Best Picture. It had everything going for it, including a standout festival run and universal acclaim. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Ben Bardsley ordered to pay £14,000 in legal costs over 'nonsense' claimA man who sued after claiming an accident left him afraid of heights lost his claim after video emerged of him careening down Europe’s tallest waterslide.&nbspBen Bardsley, of Stockport, Greater Manchester, made the personal injury claim after&nbspfalling into a koi carp pond which was being dug in his garden in 2015.The 38-year-old bodybuilder said the incident left him scared of heights and unable to lift weights, according to the BBC.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesBut Manchester County Court dismissed his claim as “nonsense” after insurance company Aviva, which was acting for the pond supplier, uncovered a social media post which showed Mr Bardsley on top of the 108ft Verti-Go waterslide in Benidorm, Spain.&nbspThe video showed Mr Bardsley hurtling down the slide at speeds of up to&nbsp62mph.&nbspCreated with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Residents attempt to remove water from their property as the streets flood in Appleby-in-Westmorland, Cumbria, as Storm Ciara hits the UKEngland's Ellis Genge celebrates scoring the first try of their Six Nations match against Scotland with teammates. title: deportation uk jamaica charter flight home office detention reshawn davis
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘I was brought up here. I don’t know anything else. I made one mistake in life, and it feels like I tried to kill the Queen’A man who has been in the UK since the age of 11 and has a British baby is set to be deported on a charter flight to Jamaica within days.Reshawn Davis, 30, was detained last Friday and told he would be removed to Jamaica on 11 February – on the second charter flight to travel to the country since the Windrush scandal two years ago.He is being removed from the country on the basis that he was convicted for robbery 10 years ago under the now-unlawful “joint enterprise” rule –&nbspfor which he spent two months in prison.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe Jamaican national, who lives with his British wife&nbspand six-month-old daughter in northwest London and has not committed any crime since his conviction, said the thought of being ripped from his family and returning to a country he has not been to for 20 years terrified him.&nbspUp to 50 other Jamaican nationals have been detained in recent weeks and are set to be deported on the same charter flight, which has been the subject of mounting controversy.A draft copy of the Windrush Lessons Learned report, leaked to the media on Thursday, said ministers should consider ending the practice of deporting people who arrived in the UK as children – prompting calls for ministers to halt the removal of iniduals like Mr Davis until it is published.Detainees are meanwhile struggling to access legal services to pursue challenges against their removal directions due to a mobile phone outage at Heathrow removal centres, which the Home Office has only just begun to resolve despite being aware of the issue since 13 January.Speaking from Colnbrook removal centre following the decision, Mr Davis, who has no family or friends in Jamaica, told The Independent: “I’m so stressed out. I can’t even explain how I feel. Yes I was born in Jamaica, but I was brought up here. I don’t know anything else. I made one mistake in life, and it feels like I tried to kill the Queen.&nbsp“I look at my daughter’s pictures now every night before I go to bed. Since she was born I never had never spent a night without her until I was locked in here. I still reach for her when I wake up. I’m not one of those to leave my wife to do it by herself. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Frank Fahey helped blow the future vice-president's White House ambitions in 1987 –&nbspbut, he tells The Independent,&nbspa lot has changed since thenIn the autumn&nbspof 1987, Frank Fahey found himself in the crosshairs of Joe Biden, then a young senator from Delaware who unleashed an angry outburst at a small event early in his first run for president.&nbspAt a home in western New Hampshire, Fahey figured he would ask a question about a brewing scandal for the future vice president about his academic record, but the stress of Biden’s first presidential run –&nbspwhich was already beleaguered by claims that he had plagiarised a speech on the campaign trail –&nbspseemed to get the better of him.“We just went to a house party and Biden was there because he was a candidate for the nomination,” Fahey tells&nbspThe Independent. “And I asked him what I thought was just an innocent question and he pretty much knocked me off the wall.”Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIt was an flare-up caught on C-Span cameras, and spread throughout the country with pre-internet virality. Responding in a way that in 2020 seems remarkably Trumpian –&nbsp“I think I probably have a much higher IQ than you do, I suspect” – Biden put one of the last nails in the coffin for his campaign, and dropped out of the race shortly after.But, some 33 years later, Fahey says&nbspthat he is ready to vote for Biden during his third race. If anything, the mere fact that Biden was on the campaign trail so long ago when someone like Pete Buttigieg was kindergarten-age underscores an experience Fahey values deeply: “I think he has had so much experience between his 36 years in the Senate and eight years as Obama’s vice president.Created with Sketch.Democratic candidates compete on the campaign trail: In pictures Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A man holds up a sign criticising billionaires in the presidential race in front of Michael Bloomberg in Compton, Califronia. I think he knows the people to get a good team of advisers around him, so I think he could make an outstanding president.”With just two days until the New Hampshire primary, all signs point towards a disappointing third run for Biden, even as he has insisted that he could lose in both of the first two states in the primary season –&nbsphe came in fourth place in the Iowa caucuses last week –&nbspand still mount a comeback in Nevada and South Carolina.Biden escalates attack on Buttigieg before tepid performance in NHIn New Hampshire,&nbspBiden has been campaigning around the state, but doing his best to manage expectations as enthusiasm has seemed to shift away from him and towards candidates like Pete Buttigieg, Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar.On Friday night, early in the final debate in Manchester before voters head to the polls in the Granite State, Biden all but conceded defeat early. “I took a hit in Iowa”, he acknowledged, “and I’ll probably take it here”.It was a statement that was realistic, given the polls. According to Real Clear Politics, Biden has seen his polling tank, and currently sits in third place behind Sanders and Buttigieg. He’s just a tad ahead of Warren in aggregates of Granite State polls, though her numbers have shown much less volatility as the former vice president has cratered.Fahey didn’t seem to mind that Biden’s polls might not look so great. But&nbsphe was offended by the concession, just days before the primary,&nbspas volunteers across the state would have been gearing up to head out into 10F&nbsp(-12C) weather to knock on doors for him, or spend their weekend making calls trying to boost his support.“I know for a fact having talked to some today that it’s discouraging to hear him say something like that with his supporters still out there working hard on the phone and knocking on doors as they are,” he says.On Saturday night, just a day after the debates, those volunteers and supporters didn’t seem to show up to support the vice president, either. title: praise british coast people
story: But rarely in all the debate about what our future now holds do you hear about the wonders of our coastline — which, when you think we have more than , miles of it, doesn’t feel right.Presenting Our Coast with Mehreen Baig, I’ve seen just how beautul it is, and how many brilliant people live their lives there.They are a special breed of unsung heroes.It can be tough for sure, in places the rest of us used to holiday — places we profess to love, often without actually doing that much to nurture.There are challenges in many coastal communities, and they definitely need the money politicians of all stripes have promised them.But I’ve also been struck by how hard they’re working to turn things around themselves. There is often hope where we may first see ­dficulty. You just have to look a bit harder sometimes.In Portpatrick, at Scotland’s bottom left corner, the harbour had fallen into miserable disrepair. A plan was hatched to stop the rot.A local hero organised a share issue for locals to raise the money to buy the harbour and restore the buildings around it. The village now has its pecker up again and the future looks bright.It’s a similar story on Anglesey. At Halen Mon a thriving family business draws water out of the Menai Strait, harvests the salt and sells it all over the world.Near there I met a woman called Sian Sykes who cared about those waters so much she paddle-boarded  miles around Anglesey picking out the plastic.Asthat wasn’t enough, she then paddled the whole coast of Wales doing exactly the same.But my favourite character round there is no longer with us. On the very western tip of Holy Island off Anglesey’s west coast, there is the South Stack lighthouse. It’s been saving sailors from watery deaths since .A hundred years ago, John Jones was its keeper and it was his great granddaughter Denise Shaw who took me up to the top of it.Denise showed me a photograph of her great-grandad sporting a magnicent moustache the seagulls must have coveted for their nests.He was no loner, though. Denise remembers her mum saying old great-gramps was a bit of a ladies’ man.And what a chat-up line he had at his disposal: “Do you want to come back to my place to see how bright my light is ”All four of the areas we’ve looked at for this series of Our Coast are around the Irish Sea. I had a brilliant time at Belfast docks where I joined the harbour pilots, whose work astounded me.It’s their job to bring the giant ships safely into port.I sort of assumed they did this by chugging out to meet them, lighting up a sign saying, “follow me” and gently leading them to their berths.Far from it. Round the clock, all year round, whatever the weather, they race out several miles to pull up alongside these huge vessels.Incredibly, a rope ladder is dropped over the side for the pilots to clamber aboard, make their way to the bridge, take over the controls and steer these monsters into tight spaces on the docks.The ship I boarded with them, somewhat terried, was carrying grain from Romania.As my man took the helm I asked the Polish skipper which country had the best harbour pilots. “You do,” he said, with feeling.Back across the Irish Sea, in Formby, north of Liverpool, I met Mike McComb in the £million place he’s built himself a stone’s throw from the sea.He has more bedrooms, bathrooms and children than I could count .His fortune could have bought him a lavish home anywhere in the world. But it was up here, along the endless beach, that back in the day he and his mates would come on their bikes from their tiny homes in Bootle.So, he tells me as we stand on the beach, lashed by rain and wind, you can keep St Tropez or Malibu. This coast, his coast, is where he’ll stay.The sea seems to be a magnet for the most memorable people, from Grace the crane engineer in Belfast Docks who played rugby for Ireland in three rugby world cups, to Sandy the tattooed pagan near Stranraer who says the sea’s our mother, and the Bulgarian dissident I chanced upon sitting in a hot tub ­surveying Liverpool from the deck of the Queen Mary .My grandad used to tell me that when you put your toe in the sea you’re connected with the whole world.With that in mind, I’ve enjoyed many a paddle this summer reflecting on the power and history of what our island nation is all about.And I urge you to do it, too. After all, it’s pretty easy. Britain’s most landlocked place — Coton in the Elms in Derbyshire — is just  miles from the coast. So none of us is more than a couple of hours away from the sea.There’s never been a more relevant time to get out to the edges and see the soul of this country.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kirk douglas was the one and only spartacus and he had balls of steel
story: When Kirk came into the world, the Battle of the Somme was still raging and Sir Ernest Shackleton — my own hero — was fighting to save his men on a doomed Antarctic expedition.At , Kirk’s death was not unexpected. But it saddened us all because it felt like this incredible human being would go on for ever.He headed the Douglas dynasty with a zest for le that put the rest of us to shame and was one of our final links to Hollywood’s golden age.Long before actors ostentatiously wore their hearts on their sleeves and made self-aggrandising speeches about the latest trendy cause, Kirk determinedly set out to do the right thing, regardless of any impact on his career.In the Fties, at the height of the Cold War, he stood up to a paranoid US government that considered anyone to the left of Genghis Khan a Soviet sympathiser.The McCarthy witchhunts ruined careers and wrecked lives, but Kirk dug in his heels and hired blacklisted writer Dalton Trumbo to work on Spartacus, which would become Kirk’s most famous movie.That took balls of steel.Kirk gave millions to charity and was a US Goodwill Ambassador, receiving the Presidential Medal of Freedom from Jimmy Carter in .He experienced heartache with the death of his son Eric from an overdose and the jailing of grandson Cameron for drug offences.But even a near-fatal helicopter crash and a stroke couldn’t defeat Kirk.His son Michael — a superstar in his own right, of course — told me last year his dad worked out almost every day with a personal trainer and remained as sharp as a tack, keeping the whole extended family on their toes.I was lucky enough to interview Kirk back in my days with TV-am.The Beeb would fly them over from LA and put them up in a posh hotel.All we could offer was a hearty breakfast, plus the chance to talk about themselves and their new project for as long as they liked.There were no pesky managers and PRs to go through.Bette Davis, Burt Lancaster, Lauren Bacall and Sammy Davis Jnr all popped into our studio at the crack of sparrows, staying for the duration of the show.Kirk was here in , promoting Dance With The Devil, a racy novel that bore a passing resemblance to his extraordinary le story.After his Jewish parents escaped persecution in Russia, Kirk was born and raised in a poor area of New York.It is a real rags-to-riches tale. His dad actually worked as a rag-and-bone man.Kirk never forgot where he came from, which is perhaps why he became a champion for justice and a fairer society.He was a delight that morning and even laughed when the crew declared, “I’m Spartacus”, one after another in his honour — though he must have seen it done hundreds of times before.He was a also a much-loved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather.The Douglas clan will be in mourning but they can celebrate a le well lived.This weekend, I am on a Kirk Douglas marathon, starting with Paths Of Glory, before The Bad And The Beautul, Ace In The Hole, The Vikings, Lust For Le and, of course, Spartacus.Tomorrow’s Oscars will rightly honour him. We won’t see his like again.I WAS honoured to host The Millies this week.It is a wonderful event run by The Sun to salute our Armed Forces and give us all a chance to say a huge thank you.As always, there were astonishing stories of bravery, courage and self-sacrice.And as always, our lovely winners told me they were nothing special, just doing their job.I honestly don’t think they realise just how remarkable they are, or how much we owe them.One of my highlights was seeing -year-old Private Fin Doherty collect his award for inspiring others.Fin was just six when his paratrooper big brother JJ was killed in action in Afghanistan.Fin was determined to follow in JJ’s footsteps to honour his brother’s memory, and join the Parachute Regiment.He has been an outstanding addition and, in an emotional ceremony, was presented with JJ’s beret in December.Their mum Joyce admits she struggled with Fin’s decision to sign up, following the death of her eldest son.But she knew it was all Fin wanted – and she is so very proud of him.We honestly don’t deserve such an inspirational young man. But thank the Lord we have him on our side.NOTHING has changed. Phillip Schofield is exactly the same person he was before he felt the time was right to tell the world he’s gay.He’s still a loving father and husband and will still host his TV shows with consummate professionalism and skill.As Phillip said himself, you never know what people are struggling with every day and, for him, it was time to be honest with himself and everyone .I’m really glad that he has made the decision and very proud of him, although obviously it can’t have been easy.There’s been lots of tears, sleepless nights and a great deal of soul-searching. I hope he now finds peace of mind.He is a very lucky man to have a family and friends who love him very much and just want him to be happy.He also has a loyal fan base who love watching him on This Morning and that won’t change. Why would it Of course, he can expect a small number of bigots and homophobes to spew out hateful bile, but they are to be pitied and ignored.Those carping about why he took so long also need to shut up.People should be allowed to come out when it feels the right time for them.Phillip began his career at a time when being openly gay in a TV presenting role was just not an option.Thank goodness things have changed and he can be open now – and know that the overwhelmingly vast majority of us wish him and his family nothing but the very best.I was really touched by what he said about interviewing brave people on This Morning, and realising that he had to be just like them and tell his truth.Love comes in many dferent forms.Phillip and his we Stephanie adore each other and that won’t change. Again, why on earth would it At the end of his statement Phillip urged us all to be kind, especially to his family, and I hope we all take those words on board.Let’s wish them all the best and let them get on with their lives.WHAT a furore over a bare shoulder. Actress-turned-MP Tracy Brabin didn’t deserve the vitriol about her outfit but it WAS distracting.It’s unfortunate because Tracy was making important points about journalists being shut out of No  briefings – a move that makes my blood run cold and threatens Press freedom. Sadly, no one was really listening.Tracy told me she had been at a music event and didn’t expect to be back in the House. She is bemused by all the fuss.How those in public le dress should not detract from their message, be it a female MP in a low-cut top or mini-skirt, or a man wearing a gaudy tie or tight trousers.Our MPs are not known for their style and rarely make headlines for their fashion sense.I am very happy for them to keep it that way.WELL, that was a rather ill-advised memo to send, reminding local councils to fly the Union Flag on February  as a “celebration” of Prince Andrew’s birthday.I had no idea this was a “thing” and that Andrew was on a list of VIPs whose birthdays are marked with a flag waving on the roof of our town halls, instead of just cake and prosecco like the rest of us.Unsurprisingly, this ludicrous edict has caused much disgruntlement.As we know, Andrew has been booted out of The Firm by his own mum after that disastrous TV interview delving into his friendship with the American paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.Then there is the ongoing scandal over whether or not Andrew will be interviewed by the FBI as part of its investigations into child trafficking allegations against Epstein.It is all very sordid and murky. Surely even his nearest and dearest would agree this is not the time for official celebrations.He is no longer a working royal and has no place on that list.Time to lower the flags for good. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits coronavirus wuhan milton keynes final flight
story: The plane - the second and last to be chartered by the British Government - arrived at RAF Brize Norton before passengers in face masks were bundled onto buses to Milton Keynes.On the flight were  Brit nationals and their family members along with  European nationals.  A team of  staff and medics were also on board.The group will now be housed in Kents Hill Park, a conference centre and hotel, for two weeks in a desperate attempt to stop any spread of the killer virus.The passengers were seen wearing face masks as they were ushered off the plane and onto waiting buses before finally arriving at their accommodation.They were met by medics and supplies including clothes and toiletries.Coronavirus has now claimed more lives than the  SARS outbreak as the global death toll climbed to more than  yesterday.And fears the killer virus is spreading have continued as the fourth case in the UK was recorded today.Todays flight the final plane to leave the Chinese city, which is the epicentre of the outbreak.They were today welcomed to quarantine with a letter, recognising the  days were likely to be challenging.The ambulance service said the presence of the group in Milton Keynes, Bucks, does not present a risk to local people.A spokesman said: The local site has been chosen because it offers appropriate accommodation and other facilities for those coming back from Wuhan while they stay in Milton Keynes.It also allows their health to be regularly monitored and has the necessary medical facilities close at hand should they be required.All staff working at the facility will wear appropriate protective equipment at all times.Brits who ed on a flight last month were taken to Arrowe Park Hospital on the Wirral.It comes after five Brits - including a nine-year-old boy - contracted the bug after it was passed to them by the third UK citizen to catch the disease.The man picked up the virus at a business conference in Singapore and then travelled to ski chalet in France where  people he came into contact with are now in hospital.Meanwhile British honeymooner was taken to hospital after he and dozens of other passengers tested positive for the virus on the Diamond Princess cruise ship, which is quarantined off Yokohama in Japan.Alan Steele, from Wolverhampton, said on Friday that he was being taken to hospital while his we, Wendy, remained on board the ship.There are  people with British passports - including crew - among the nearly , passengers and crew on the ship.Princess Cruises said an additional  people, including Mr Steele, had tested positive for the virus on the Diamond Princess, taking the total number of cases to .The company said the quarantine on the ship was due to end on February , barring unforeseen developments, and confirmed that all the affected guests were being taken to hospital.There are no plans to fly anyone off the ship and back to the UK at the moment.A separate ship in Hong Kong, the World Dream, has about  British passport holders on board. Nobody on that ship has tested positive.Meanwhile, the World Health Organisationhas shown that the reported number of new cases has fallen over the past two days, which experts welcomed with caution.There were roughly , new cases reported worldwide on February , , on February  and , on February  - the vast majority in China, WHO figures show.Patients in England with the virus will be transferred to one of four High Consequences Infectious Diseasesunits.These include two in London - the Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust and Guys and St Thomas NHS Foundation Trust, where the third victim is understood to have been taken.There are also two in the north of the country - Royal Liverpool and Broadgreen University Hospitals NHS Trust and Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.Two other patients who tested positive for the virus last week in York are still being treated at the Royal Victoria Infirmary infectious diseases centre in Newcastle.Access to these units is restricted to a team of trained medical staff who are made to wear protective gowns, face maks, visors and gloves before they can enter.In some cases, patients will have a specially-designed tent with a ventilator set up around their bed. But experts warned it is not yet clearthis represents an actual fall in cases or whether the fall will prove sustainable.The Department of Health and Social Care said that  people in the UK have been tested for coronavirus as of pm Friday, with three cases confirmed.It is understood that the third person in the UK to be diagnosed with coronavirus caught the illness in Singapore.He is reported to be a middle-aged British man and is understood to be the first UK national to contract the disease.The man is thought to have been diagnosed in Brighton and was transferred to St Thomas Hospital in London, where there is an infectious disease unit, on Thursday afternoon.Professor Keith Willett, NHS strategic incident director, said the patient had called the NHS  service after becoming concerned.After a telephone assessment, they were advised to make their way to Royal Sussex County Hospital Brighton for testing, he said.Following a pre-arranged plan with the NHS they drove themselves to the hospital, were tested in isolation and away from public areas of the hospital, and ed home in isolation in their own car.Two other patients, who had recently travelled from China, are still being treated at the Royal Victoria Infirmary infectious diseases centre in Newcastle.One is a student at the University of York, while the other is a family member. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: andrew tip caroline dont speak out
story: And then straight away I started wondering about the more important things in le such as: What shall I have for breakfast I think that she ended up in court and I have it in my mind that she pleaded not guilty.I’m also fairly sure that she’s not allowed to speak with her boyfriend until the case comes to court. But I can’t be sure, as I have other things to think about like: I need some new trousers.Then out of the blue she announced on social media that she was going to speak out because “mine and my families le is no longer up for entertainment or gossip”.“Wow,” I thought. “That’s amazing. She doesn’t know how to use apostrophes.”It turns out, however, that while she can’t write properly, she can at least think straight because she never did speak out. Which means she stopped the story from rearing up again.If only Prince Andrew was as bright. We were all dimly aware that he knew a man in America who’d had lots of sex with young girls.And that one day, this man had been found dead in a police cell. Then we went back to wonderingwe needed more washing-up liquid.Prince Andrew, however, decided that instead of letting the story die down by not saying anything, he’d go on television to set the record straight.It was a disaster. He was suddenly front-page news all over the world and he looked guilty as hell.Of what, we weren’t sure. But whatever it was, we all worked out that as he has a Bentley, he could definitely have got from a Pizza Express restaurant in Woking to the centre of London in less than six hours.A few weeks later, as the story was withering once more, Hank J Dieselburger, an American prosecutor involved in the dead sex-man’s case, announced that the FBI had received “zero co-operation” from Prince Andrew.You’d think Andrew would have learned from his earlier mistake. You’d think he’d do a Flack and say nothing.But no. The very next day, “friends” of the Prince — which is another way of saying “the Prince” — went on the attack, telling reporters he was angry and bewildered. “They haven’t even approached me — I mean him.”The problem is that ego-fed celebrities read every single thing that is written about them. And they believe everyone  is reading everything, as well.We aren’t. We don’t really care. So when you attempt to clear your name, it’s like trying to put out a fire with petrol.It’s better for Andrew, and the whole Royal Family,he takes a leaf from singer Ronan Keating’s book — “You say it best, when you say nothing atThen, perhaps, he could take a leaf from his nephew’s book. And bugger off to Canada.I’M not defending drugs here, but when you see someone giggling their way through a packet of frozen peas and some leftover sherry trle at five in the morning, it’s easy to see why someone might think: “Yes, that cannabis malarkey looks like fun. I shall give it a go.”It’s the same story with cocaine.You see a dullard finding himself absolutely fascinating at a party and you think: “I’ll have a crack at that.”But this new drug, flakka, is dferent.One man who took it ate a homeless man’s face. Another gouged her own mother’s eyes out. And a third cut off his own penis.Which raises an interesting point. Why would anyone look at someone cutting off his old fella and think, “Ooh, I’ll have what he’s having ”A BUNCH of people who think the Lake District should only be used by ramblers decided to stage a protest over plans to put ten small tourist yachts on Grasmere lake.However, before the protest could take place, the idea was abandoned. And guess what  Yup. The protest went ahead anyway.They were actually protesting about something that wasn’t going to happen. Which proves what I’ve suspected for quite some time. Ramblers aren’t entirely right in the head.Next week, they will be protesting about the sonic booms made by Concorde and the burning of witches.LAST Sunday, driving was banned in the Italian city of Milan.Who thought that was a good idea  Getting an Italian to leave his car at home is impossible. It’s a part of his being, like his liver and his lungs.Needless to say, the scheme was not very successful.So not very successful in fact that, in the first three hours, the police had issued  fines. And the authorities now admit the ban was “largely ignored”.THERE’S much talk at the moment about how internet shopping is killing the High Street. But I’m not one of the murderers.When the time comes for my annual clothes shopping trip, I simply head to the Levi’s store on Regent Street in London, point at the label on the back of the jeans I’m wearing and ask for three more pairs just the same.I love Levi’s. I’ve worn nothing  since I was  and I’ve always loved their shop, the staff have always been brilliant. They always have what I need in stock and they never ask for my phone number or email address. I’m in and out in two minutes flat.This year, though, there was a disaster. There were two disinterested youths in there who looked at the label on the back of my jeans and said, “We don’t make those any more.”WHAT  ! !On the verge of fainting with shock, I dragged them back from their interesting conversation about Stormzy and was told in an exasperated fashion that I could still buy them online.This begs a question. What’s the point of having an expensive-to-run shopyou then fill it with people who tell you to go home and buy what you need on the net PETA, an organisation for animal enthusiasts who like to wear clothes made from crude oil, have announced that people often see their pet dog as nothing more than a cheap burglar alarm.Cheap You can buy a home alarm kit these days for less than £, whereas a proper dog is going to be way more than that.Plus, you only need feed an alarm with a tiny amount of electricity to keep it running, whereas a dog requires a bed, a blanket, food, water and, later on, vets bills that will make your eyes water.THIS week, a car crashed through my fence, turning it and an expensive new gate into matchsticks.By the time I got there, the car was gone. But there was still a lot of “police aware” tape fluttering about in the breeze.So I called the nearest station, which was approximately  miles away, as I needed to contact the driver to talk about insurance. Sadly, however, while the police are “aware” of the incident, they are not prepared to give me any details.Mustn’t grumble, though. While it will cost a few hundred quid to get everything mended, I must accept that the police have much more important things to do, such as investigating dead people who weren’t paedophiles.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc no longer loved broadcaster
story: If you are a lavishly overpaid BBC presenter or senior manager with your snout stuffed deep into the corporation’s publicly-funded trough, then three quid is nothing — around the price of a semi-skimmed latte made with almond milk from that delightful little café outside Broadcasting House.But coming when it did — immediately after the BBC’s wretchedly biased coverage of the moment we left the European Union — hiking the archaic telly tax felt grotesquely provocative.And I realised that the BBC’s big problem today is that it is unloved. The young folk born this century, like my -year-old daughter, do not watch it. The BBC means nothing to Generation YouTube.And the millions of us who grew up with the Beeb no longer recognise it as the benign Auntie that gave us Doctor Who, Top Of The Pops, Le On Earth, Fawlty Towers, The Likely Lads and David Dimbleby staying up all night at the General Election.That old beloved BBC — endlessly entertaining, scrupulously fair — is dead now. The BBC’s coverage of the night we left the European Union was nothing less than shameful.Here was a moment of truly historical signicance, the kind of national event that the BBC was born to cover. And it was dished up like a dull night at the Eurovision Song Contest.Down in Parliament Square, awash with Union Jacks and peaceful, happy patriots, BBC reporter Geeta Guru-Murthy blurted: “It’s a very white crowd mostly” — to the bewilderment of the many black and Asian people who were there to celebrate.But, of course, the BBC continues to peddle the filthy little lie that Brexit has its roots in the racism of the bigoted British people.Meanwhile, Sophie Raworth sat primly in a BBC studio made up to look like the EU flag. The studio never turned red, white and blue. There was no sense that the largest vote for anything in British history was being honoured. Why must we pay £billion a year for this one-sided garbage My colleague Ally Ross has pointed out that BBC “comedy” shows like Have I Got News For You, Frankie Boyle’s New World Order and The Mash Report have all been larded with anti-Brexit orthodoxy for years. Now the predictably loony Remainer-speak even seeps into the poison the BBC drips into our children.On the day we left the EU, the BBC released a CBBC Horrible Histories special mocking British stupidity.Queen Victoria was accused of callously sweetening her tea with sugar harvested by slaves — even though slavery was abolished four years before Victoria came to the throne.Historian Andrew Roberts described the mocking film as “a stream of bigoted hatred directed at this country”. They truly don’t get it in Broadcasting House. Millions of licence fee payers are deeply offended by the BBC’s relentlessly anti-British, anti-Brexit sentiment.It is why we fell out of love with the BBC. There is talk about decriminalising non-payment of the licence fee, or making payment optional. But the BBC no longer represents the entire nation. It peddles the prejudices of the disappointed elite who run it.The BBC does not speak for the British people. It doesn’t even seem to like us very much. So why should we pay anything at all for this crap AFTER being overlooked at the Oscars for her sensational performance in Hustlers, the half-time show at the Super Bowl felt like the revenge of Jenner Lopez.But Hustlers is my favourite film of the past  months. Lopez deserved an Oscar for her role.And whoever wins Best Actress at the Oscars tonight, I bet they can’t slide down a pole like her.MICHELLE OBAMA always said: “When they go low, we go high.”Meaning that when the Republican opponents of President Obama struck a low blow the Obamas had a strict policy of keeping their cool, their dignity and the moral high ground.The most senior Democratic politician in America just failed to take Michelle Obama’s advice. At his State of the Union address, President Trump petulantly refused to shake the hand of NancyPelosi, the Democratic Speaker of the House of Representatives. Pelosi should have shrugged off Trump’s rudeness and perhaps laughed in Donald’s orange face.Instead, clearly boiling with rage, Nancy ripped a copy of Trump’s speech to pieces. As the speech was full of optimistic stuff about making America a fairer, more prosperous place, the only person Pelosi humiliated was herself.The Democrats are starting to make Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour Party look like an effective opposition.THE classic James Bond films – Dr No, From Russia With Love, Goldfinger – were all less than two hours long.But in the modern fashion for over-long movies – The Irishman clocks in at three hours and  minutes – the next Bond film, No Time To Die, will be the longest ever at almost three hours.Let’s hope that means plenty of Ana de Armas, , as Bond girl Paloma. And not too much of Daniel Craig, , moaning about ’s dodgy knees.Teenage girls are messier than teenage boys. But teenage boys are, in my experience, more likely to leave takeaway pizza under the bed for six months for the mice to nibble.And when vermin move in, you really long for your little darling to move out.SUCKING up to the millionaire snowflakes in the audience, Prince William complained about the lack of ersity at the Baftas.I don’t believe it. This year a black actor, Micheal Ward, won the Rising Star Bafta for gang film Blue Story. Six years ago,  Years A Slave won Best Picture, competing with epic Hollywood fare like Gravity.If the film or performance is good enough, then the Baftas is colour blind.The real lack of ersity is among British actors. These days most of them went to Eton with Prince William. Now that’s what I call a lack of ersity.A SURVEY reveals that  per cent of Canadians are against paying the £million to-£million-a-year security bill for Harry and Meghan’s new le.Wherever they lay their hats, from Toronto to Tinsel Town, there is only one sucker who will ever pay for Harry and Meghan’s security. The poor old British taxpayer.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: dad uk since 11 and has baby with brit mum to be deported to jamaica
story: Reshawn Davis, , who has a baby with his British we, was detained last Friday and told he would be removed to Jamaica on Tuesday.He said he was terried about ing to Jamaica and feared he would be targeted.The -year-old is being booted out the UK because of a robbery conviction from  years ago. Mr Davis spent two months in jail.He was convicted under the joint enterprise law that was used to convict people in gang-related casesdefendants could have foreseen violent acts by their associates.In  the Supreme Court ruled the law had been wrongly interpreted for  years.Mr Davis, who lives with his Brit we and six-month-old daughter in northwest London, has not committed any crime since his conviction.He is set to be deported with around  other Jamaican nationals on Tuesday.Boris Johnson said it was right to send back foreign national offenders.Speaking from Colnbrook removal centre following the decision, Mr Davis, who has no family or friends in Jamaica, told The Independent: Im so stressed out. I cant even explain how I feel.Yes I was born in Jamaica, but I was brought up here. I dont know anything . I made one mistake in le, and it feels like I tried to kill the Queen.I look at my daughters pictures now every night before I go to bed. Since she was born I never had never spent a night without her until I was locked in here.I still reach for her when I wake up. Im not one of those to leave my we to do it by herself. I want to be there for them both.Im terried to go to Jamaica. My cousin was deported and he has now died. People will be hostile to me because Ive been deported. Im going to be targeted.His we of five years, Tonique Kerr, , said her husbands deportation would prevent her from going back to work and force her to have to claim welfare benefits.Ms Kerr, who is currently on maternity leave but works as a complaints handler at an energy company, told the newspaper: I had been hoping to go back to work so he could look after the baby. I wont be able to. Thats not something I wanted because I dont want to sit down and rely on benefits. Ive always worked. Ive never been on benefits in my le.I never imagined being a single mum. I dont want to fall into the statistics of young single parents, especially for something that isn’t my fault and could have been prevented. Its hard, emotionally and I would need help financially because it is hard having a young baby.Reshawn is a great dad. Hes been here all the time with her. She loved him. He does a lot – feeds her, changes her, plays with her. A child needs their dad. I don’t know what’s going to happen now.Mr Davis MP, Dawn Butler, said she objected to him being branded a serious criminal.The shadow women and equalities minister said: His we feels like this stress is going to kill her husband because he has a heart problem.She backed calls for the flight to Kingston to be halted until we establish the true facts of the situation.Mr Davis lawyer argued that he should be allowed to remain in the UK because of his family ties.However it was ruled on Friday that he did not have a genuine and subsisting relationship with his we or daughter and that it would not be unduly harsh for them to be without him.In a Parliamentary briefing last week, the Joint Council for Welfare of Immigrants said it was concerned some of the passengers could be potential victims of trafficking or victims of county lines exploitation.The issue was raised at Prime Ministers Questions, when Labour MP Nadia Whittome called for the flight to be halted until a review into the lessons learnt from the Windrush scandal was published and its recommendations implemented.The Windrush scandal saw many of those who had arrived in Caribbean countries between  and  detained or deported despite having the right to live in the UK for decades. The fallout led to the resignation of Amber Rudd as home secretary.A Home Office spokesperson said: The planned charter flight to Jamaica is specically for removing foreign criminals. Those detained for removal include people convicted of manslaughter, rape, violent crime and dealing class A drugs.The spokesperson added that everyone on the flight will have had their cases fully reviewed to ensure there are no outstanding legal barriers, including trafficking and slavery claims, that would prevent their removal from the UK.The law on joint enterprise was challenged in  following the case of Ameen Jogee, who had been convicted of joint enterprise murder of former Leicestershire police officer, Paul Fyffe in .While the court heard that it had been Jogees friend, Mohammed Hirsi, who stabbed Mr Fyfe in the heart, he had egged him on and both were convicted of murder and given le sentences.But during the appeal, Jogee argued he was not inside the house when the incident took place, and could not have foreseen what his friend intended to do.Delivering the judgement, Supreme Court judge Lord Neuberger said it was wrong to treat foresight as a sufficient test to convict someone of murder.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brit holidaymakers magaluf good behaviour contract
story: Tourists could also be fined £, for jumping off balconies in new measures designed to stamp out drunken tourism in party resorts.Hotels who fail in a new legal obligation to kick out guests engaging in the dangerous practice, known locally as balconing, have also been told to expect the same type of fines.A document drafted by the Majorca hotel federation FEHM has been sent to its member hotels in Magaluf and the nearby S’Arenal resort.It states: “The hotel management informs clients that it is forbidden to engage in practices which endanger le, health and physical integrity in this establishment, for example by passing from a balcony or window to another and jumping from unsuitable locations into the swimming pool.“Guests who carry out these dangerous practices will be expelled immediately by hotel management, with the assistance of the forces of law and ordernecessary.”Holidaymakers where hotels decide to implement the change will be asked to sign and date the document and record their passport and room numbers at check-in.The code of conduct also highlights the fines that can be levied on guests who break the rules and warns them: “We also inform you that taking drinks of any kind outside the hotel is strictly prohibited.”Maria Jose Aguilo, vice-president of the FEHM which has  member hotels in Majorca, said the association was recommending the introduction of the document but confirmed it was “optional.”She told  local paper Ultima Hora: “The only objective here is to offer more legal protection in case of claims.”Officials at the association said was too early to say what the take-up by hotels would be.The new decree against drunken tourism was announced on January  and took effect following its publication in an Official State Gazette five days later.It was approved by regional MPs on Tuesday. Only far-right wing party Vox voted against ratying the decree, branding it “discriminatory” and “botched” and predicting it would lead to job losses.The decree covers Magaluf, S’Arenal and the West End part of San Antonio in Ibiza which is also popular with British holidaymakers.It bans pub crawls and drink offers like happy hours in those areas.The decree, valid for five years, also limits the number of alcoholic drinks served in restaurants and hotels as part of all-inclusive offers to three at lunch and three at dinner.Party boat operators are banned from picking up and dropping off revellers in the areas the law covers. And shops in the resorts will be banned from selling alcohol between .pm and am.A regional government spokesman confirmed after its introduction: “The new rules establish a penalty regime which puts special emphasis on serious and very serious misdemeanours.“Those practices which are dangerous and cause risk to le or endanger the integrity and health of clients or the tourists who engage in them, will be considered serious misdemeanours. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
