Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email HS to Manchester and Leeds has been hurled into doubt amid claims Boris Johnson will put the huge leg of the rail line under review.The Prime Minister is tipped this week to finally approve Phase One of the high-speed link from London to Birmingham - despite opposition from scores of Tory MPs. But multiple reports say he will stop short of approving Phase Two to Manchester and Leeds - instead ordering extra analysis on the costs. And today he found an unlikely ally in the Mayor of Greater Manchester - who called for staff to be moved off HS Phase  and onto east-west rail links in northern England instead. Andy Burnham offered ministers a dramatic compromise to prioritise aposNorthern Powerhouse Railapos ahead of the second leg of HS.  It is understood Mr Burnham made the offer in a bid to get ahead of the formal announcement, expected on Tuesday, and ensure funds are still won for northern transport. Mr Burnham still slammed reports there could be a review of the HS section beyond Birmingham, telling Sky News: “That sounds like the same old story to me. London to Birmingham gets a gold plated railway and we get a second-class option or maybe nothing at all. “For a government that’s claiming to be standing for the north, I think this takes them into quite dangerous territory.” But crucially he said there could be an “opportunity” for “compromise” - to prioritise east-west Northern Powerhouse Rail connections instead. “We’ve never been convinced in Greater Manchester about the design of HS on our side of the country,” he said. “If you asked people in the north which one they would prioritise, most people would say get east-west right. “So in many ways,government ministers are listening this morning, I want to make an offer to them. “If we can all agree that we now prioritise east west on the western half of the country, get the design right at [Manchester] Piccadilly, get high speed rail to Liverpool more quickly - then I think that’s something we could get behind. “Because we could look at the prospect of an east-west railways across the north opening in the s, HS is only planned to come here in the s.  “So there is room for a compromise here. Maybe it’s about taking the team who are working on HS north of Birmingham off that project and putting them on Northern Powerhouse rail.” West Midlands mayor Andy Street said he still believed the whole line would get the go-ahead. He told the BBC: I personally think the line will be given the go ahead in principle for the whole line, even though they’ll only be giving the go ahead for the building of the London-Birmingham stage, because that’s the only stage with the tenders, and that includes the rebuilding of Euston.  Askedhe had “got one over” Dominic Cummings, the Boris Johnson aide who is against the project, he said: “Yes Dominic Cummings was against it, let the battle begin!” The from London to Birmingham, Leeds and Manchester has prompted a Tory civil war amid warnings its cost could spiral from £bn to £bn.At least  Tory MPs have spoken out against the project but it has won the backing of key Cabinet ministers including the Chancellor Sajid Javid.Boris Johnson commissioned a review of the project last year by independent expert Doug Oakervee.

story: NewsTory ministers blow £k on propaganda rival to school cuts info websiteEXCLUSIVE Millions of parents check how much their kids school budgets have been slashed with SchoolCuts.org.uk - but the Government have set up their own version which paints a rosier pictureShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  FEB News " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMinisters have been accused of blowing more than £, on a “propaganda” website about school funding. The new site appears to be a bid to compete with SchoolCuts, a search engine that allows parents to look up how much cash their childrenaposs school budget has been slashed. But unlike SchoolCuts, which is run by teaching unions, the government’s website ignores the impact of inflation, increases in staff pay and other costs. Education Minister Nick Gibb confirmed the Government had spent £, building the website.Lib Dem Education spokesperson Layla Moran, who uncovered the cost of the page using Parliamentary Questions, branded it “propaganda” - and blamed Boris Johnson’s right-hand man Dominic Cummings.Both websites allow parents to search by school or local authority. But while SchoolCuts shows how much funding has decreased in real terms since , the government’s Skills Funding site only accounts for changes between   and  . And it doesn’t adjust the figure for inflation.  The research behind SchoolCuts has been declared a fair representation of the state of education funding by the independent Institute for Fiscal Studies. Kevin Courtney, Joint General Secretary of the National Education Union, said: “The School Cuts website run by the National Education Union gives parents the information they need to see what the real picture for funding is in their school. “The Government’s website doesn’t account for inflation and it only shows changes since  – ignoring all the cuts the Government has made since . “So this website really isn’t very useful to parents and therefore every penny spent on it is a penny wasted”.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA grandad claims he cooks healthy and homemade meals for four on a budget of just £ a week - and heaposs shared his tips. Deit Deitreich-Briggs, , looks after his grandchildren five or six days a week from am to pm, plus a couple of nights, to enable his daughters to work. The Birmingham pensioner loves to cook for Lacey, eight, Indie, six, and Zayn, six, and also collects them from school, helps them with homework and supports them during their out of school activities. Running to a tight budget on his pension, Mr Deitreich-Briggs says he manages to feed the four of them for just £ a week.Among the dishes he prepares for the children, there are homemade fish and chips, pizza and mini toad in the holes, Birmingham Live reports.At the weekend, the kids often like to help their grandad bake chocolate and vanilla cakes for them to eat during the week. “I love having a close bond with my grandchildren and wouldn’t want it any other way,” the retired retail manager said. I’m proud of my daughters and their careers, and glad I can help them to have the lestyles they need to be able to work and have children. I enjoy making all our food from scratch, ensuring itaposs healthy and balanced, and teaching the children to cook too. Mr Deitreich-Briggs, from Erdington, Birmingham, is a widower so he cares for his grandchildren on his own.  We have an extremely good breakfast every day and then they go off to school laughing and happy, said Deit, they are doing well and are happy, they’ve got that stability. They also do their homework every morning before going to school. He gives them tea at pm then takes them to football, swimming and the gym before their parents come to collect them. The -year-old, who is a yoga teacher, then goes to work. Among his tips to cook healthy meals on a budget, Deit said it is important to plan and prepare ahead, make sure nothing is wasted. Other tips include storing leftovers, shopping at value supermarkets, using honey instead of sugar and getting the kids a meal chart.  His daughter Amii Deitreich-Worthington, , is a corporate travel consultant and lives just down the road in Erdington. She said: My and my husband wouldn’t be able to both work full time without dad, he takes the pressure off us. It’s nice that the children have that special time with their grandad. When I was younger, I used to spend a lot of time with my nan. It’s great to have a dferent role model in your le who brings dferent ideas on how to do things. Amii, whose husband Ross works as a sht manager, added: The children learn a lot from their grandad. He has more time than we do and helps them with their homework. It’s such a big pressure having to get homework done and trying to get to after school clubs when you’re working full time.  It’s great that he makes sure they eat healthily too. We totally trust him to make the right decisions. When the kids are in his care, it’s his rules and what he wants to teach them. His daughter Zita Deitreich-Irving, , works as a part time legal secretary so her son Indie goes to his grandadaposs three days a week.  On the days when she is not at work, Zita meets her dad, niece and nephew to do the school run together and she helps Deit take them swimming on a Monday too. Dad is a massive help, we wouldnapost be able to do it without him, said Zita, who lives in Erdington and is married to Neil, a plumbing and heating engineer. It means by the time me and my husband get back from work, Indie has had his dinner and so he doesnapost have to wait to eat at pm at night. Dad was just the same with us when we were kids, he loves it. We love that he has that close bond with them and that the cousins see each other every day. When dadaposs on holiday, Amii and I will still keep the kids together, sharing the childcare the way dad does.

title: i went looking real dad
story: NewsI went looking for my real dad and found the brother I never knew I hadRoyal Navy veteran Peter Stantons lelong search for his father ended with him discovering half-brother, Larry Arnold, , who lives in FloridaShareCommentsByLouie Smith:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB News " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Royal Navy veteran who has been searching for his dad since he was a teenager has discovered he has a brother. Peter Stanton, , was raised by mum Hilda after she got pregnant following an affair with a US sailor. He began searching for his father Roland aged  and had almost given up hope. But he uploaded his DNA online and was put in touch with half-brother Larry Arnold, , who lives in Florida. Dad-of-four Peter said: “We actually look alike, it is absolutely amazing. I was over the moon. “He used to play golf and I used to play as well and there are loads of silly similar things like that. “I was really disappointed that I missed my father. He passed away in  aged  but to know I have a brother feels out of this world. “I just want to give him a hug.” The pair are now making up for lost time by chatting on Skype weekly and plan to meet in person. Larry added: “I am completely in awe of this whole thing and I am looking forward to the day we meet. “I have so many things I want to tell him about our father. “I would have loved for dad to have known Peter. He would have been so proud.” Roland joined the US Navy aged  and served as a minesweeper. He was stationed in Plymouth, Devon, when he met Hilda during preparations for the Normandy invasion.  But following the Second World War he ed to the US, leaving her pregnant and heartbroken. Peter joined the Royal Navy Gunnery Division aged  to follow in his mother’s footsteps, and served for  years. He sent DNA to ancestry five years ago but there was no match until Larry, who was in the US Army National Guard, registered himself. Larry told him Roland believed Hilda had given birth to a daughter. Peter, of Walthamstow, East London, explained: “He had a wire signal back when he ed to the States and he tried looking for the girl and could never find her and he couldn’t locate my mother either. “Obviously the signal was wrong.  “He also seems to think my mother looked pretty much like his mother, which could be the reason they got together.” Sadly the half-brothers discovered they have both suffered from types of cancer.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe best pal who once defended mass murderer Jeremy Bamber to the hilt has turned his back on him – and rubbished his new alibi. Brett Collins broke his silence for the first time in over three decades to tell why he thinks Bamber, who slaughtered his family at their sprawling Essex farmhouse in , should never be released from jail. In the years since, Brett has gone from believing in Bamber’s innocence – even getting a lawyer to defend him – to being convinced of his guilt. And describing his one-time closest friend as “a Jekyll and Hyde personality”, he said: “He should never be released from jail. He has a dark side and a nasty streak.” Brett, now  and back living in his native New Zealand where the Sunday People tracked him down on an island, spoke out on the case after hearing that Bamber was planning a new appeal against his conviction. Bamber, now , is serving le for shooting five members of his family, a crime which forms the basis of current ITV drama White House Farm. His legal team are mounting an appeal based in part on claims the real killer was inside the house and a rle was seen at a window while he was outside talking to police. But Brett today demolishes the idea that Bamber can prove he has an alibi which means he could not have been responsible for the massacre. He insisted: “He didn’t ever bring up someone being inside or being seen at the window when the police were there with him to me. It’s just bulls**t.” Describing the events of the time, he recalled: “I got a lawyer to represent Jeremy at his court case and at that stage I believed in him.  But as time has gone by, and I’ve had a lot of time to think about things, I’ve totally changed my mind. “I remember saying to him at the time, ‘You’re going to need an alibi – they might put this thing on you’. He said to me, ‘Oh, I have it. I was at home’. I said to him, ‘That doesn’t sound like much of an alibi’. “Jeremy should stop this appeal, stop stirring things up and leave people alone. He should never be released from jail.” Speaking from his cell in Wakefield jail last month Bamber said: “It is the ultimate alibi that I was in the company of dozens of police officers when it was clear that a person or persons were alive in the house who I am convicted of murdering.”  He claims his schizophrenic sister Sheila, a model known as Bambi, murdered their -year-old parents Nevill and June and her twin sons Nicholas and Daniel, six, at the house in rural Tolleshunt D’Arcy. Brett said he remembered asking Bamber immediately after the mass slaying what had been “going on” within the family. He said,‘You wouldn’t believe what went on’, but he would go no further. That was the same answer he gave me every time I asked him. “The idea that his sister would shoot the family, put the silencer away in the cupboard, and then shoot herself is just crazy.” Brett’s new testimony comes as the murders are being portrayed in the six-part TV drama White House Farm, which finishes this Wednesday. It stars Freddie Fox as Bamber and Alfie Allen from Game of Thrones as Brett.  Brett recalled how Bamber displayed no real grief over the deaths of his family, laughed at their funeral, and could not wait to blow his inheritance on women, cars and parties. He said: “At the funeral Jeremy wasn’t depressed or really down. He was making jokes and was almost theatrical. “After the murders he asked me to go to the farm with him and help him take all the valuable stuff he had picked out to go to the auctions in London. “He literally rled through the house in every hidden spot grabbing handfuls of cash. “I said, ‘Oh my God, they’re barely dead’ and he said, ‘It’s mine, I’ve got to do it sometime’. “After the funeral we were staying at what used to be his sister’s apartment in Hampstead. “There were loads of photographers and journalists outside the front door waiting for him.  He said to me, ‘Because you’ve stood by me and helped me, I’ll shout us a trip to the south of France’. “We had a wonderful two weeks and he was in the highest of humour. “You’d never think he’d been through a funeral at all. He was just full of le and looking forward to his new le with money. “That was when I first began to wonderhe’d done it, but I put it to the back of my mind. “He was constantly speaking about the inheritance he was going to get and how he’d be able to buy whatever he wanted. “He said he wanted to buy a Ferrari or Porsche and put the farm on the market as soon as possible and live as a playboy in London.” Brett added that Bamber repeatedly had wild sex with a married woman from Switzerland they had met in the expensive ski resort of St Tropez.  He said: “We went to a private beach you had to pay to get into. There was music and champagne. “An older lady sent two bottles over to us and when Jeremy went to the toilet she came over to me and saidI could get him to sleep with her she would buy us both a beautul dinner. “This went on for a week with Jeremy sleeping with this woman. She took us to the most expensive restaurants in St Tropez and some amazing nightclubs. “It made my holiday but apparently she was like a mountain lion in bed as she kept scratching all his back like you wouldn’t believe. She was married and about ten years older, but had the body of an -year-old.”  The pair were arrested at Dover when they ed from the south of France and Brett had to prove by his passport stamps he had been on holiday in Greece at the time of the murders, so could not be involved. He stood by his friend and was photographed around that time with Angela Greaves, who was reported to be Bamber’s girlfriend. He remembered: “Jeremy spoke amazingly and had a presence but he’s a Jekyll and Hyde personality. “It was like he could turn tears and sadness on when other people like the police were around, but when he was with me he was completely normal. Andhe’s in a corner he becomes lethal.”  Brett, who lives on the island of Waiheke near Auckland, first met Bamber when he went out to New Zealand to do a ing course. The pair kept in touch and resumed their friendship when Brett visited England. He recalled his surprise at finding out that Bamber, who was adopted after being born into a family of Buckingham Palace servants, hated his loving family. He said: “He told me that in his early teens he had been raped by an older man and I think that screwed him up a bit. “When I first came to England I met his father and he took us fishing. “We spent the day together but Jeremy told me he’d never really liked his father that much and he didn’t like his mother at all.  I’ve still got a very clear memory of everything that happened and I’m now sure he staged it all on the day of the murders. “He had quite a devious mind and used to love the cut and thrust of making up stuff. He had a love and greed for money. Anyone who knew him close like I did knew that money was the number one thing in his le. It wasn’t normal.

story: NewsKate Middleton proves she is royal familys new leading lady at BAFTAsThe Duchess of Cambridge proved she is the "ultimate rockstar royal" as she schmoozed A list guests at the BAFTAs while wearing a recycled Alexander McQueen gownShareCommentsByAnna Pointer:,  FEB NewsKate Middleton proves she is Royal Familys new leading lady at BAFTAs " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAs she chatted to A-listers and schmoozed with stars at the Baftas, the Duchess of Cambridge showed she was the ultimate rockstar royal. Despite weeks of turmoil following Harry and Meghan’s shock decision to swap the UK for Canada, Kate, , looked happier and more relaxed in her regal duties than ever. Wearing a recycled white and gold gown by Alexander McQueen, the mum-of-three gossiped and giggled with Judy actress Renée Zellweger – even patting the star’s arm affectionately. Kate also met  director Sam Mendes, while husband Prince William, , mingled with Hollywood heavyweights including Joker star Joaquin Phoenix. According to body language expert Judi James, Kate’s appearance at the glitzy event marks a dramatic new direction for the Duchess. Judi says: “It has been a perfect storm for the Royal Family lately but Kate has now taken on the biggest power position in the entire Firm. “She’s the new matriarch because while the Queen is strong, she’s getting older and needs that kind of support from someone she can trust.” Kate has come a long way from the shy, -year-old student who first caught William’s eye during a university fashion show in . Since marrying in to the Royal Family in April , Kate has often seemed uncomfortable in the glare of the public eye.  “In the early days, she would hide herself in William’s shadow, but it was clear from her appearance at the Baftas that all of that has totally changed,” says Judi. “She’s not remotely dependent on him any more.” However, Judi thinks that Kate’s newfound confidence has had a positive impact on Wills, too. “Seeing them hold court with superstars, it was obvious they have shted into real power couple mode. “It’s ironic, as that’s the path Harry and Meghan were meant to take, but Kate looks incredibly at ease in this new role.  The drama surrounding ‘Megxit’ – which saw Harry, , and Meghan, , controversially renounce their official duties – appears to have been the defining moment in Kate’s rise to the top of the Windsor tree.Judi says: “She’s been supporting William and acting as a mediatorduring all the recent arguments. “By playing out these complicated roles so perfectly, she has provedherself to be the royals’ big saviour.”Royal expert and author Ingrid Seward believes that the Queen, , is hugely grateful to Kate for stepping up. “She’s delighted with her,” she says.  “The Queen is very reliant on Kate because she’s so stable – and she’s simply untouchable in everything she does at the moment.” Although Ingrid does not believe Kate ever felt threatened by Meghan joining the family, she adds: “The recent fall-out between Harry and William would have been draining for her, so she’s probably feeling a huge weight off her shoulders that she doesn’t have to worry about Meghan’s influence any more.” Kate’s priorities may also be changing now that her and William’s children – George, six, Charlotte, four, and Louis, two in April – are becoming slightly more independent. “Charlotte and George are at school now, so she has more time on her hands,” Ingrid says.  “That means she can do more of what she really enjoys – and we saw that with the garden she designed at last year’s Cha Flower Show. “In earlier years, she always had to toe the line. Now she can pursue her own interests more freely.”  Kate’s popularity with the British public seems to have rebooted her sense of style, too. title: mcdonalds worker lists secrets took
story: NewsMcDonalds worker lists secrets that took him from £-an-hour to £million a yearDean Chapman, , dropped out of school before completing his A Levels but now runs a food business of four branches with a turnover of £millionShareCommentsBySanjeeta Bains:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsDean Chapman, , started his business career at McDonalds " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA McDonaldaposs employee who became the man behind four of the UKaposs biggest and busiest franchises has given his top business secrets. Dean Chapman, , snubbed university to serve burgers at McDonaldaposs and now runs a business boasting four branches with a turnover of more than £ million. The dad-of-three, from Leicester, took his first McDonaldaposs job aged  job to generate cash for a college canoeing holiday. But now, Dean and his team run restaurants at Cherry Street near Temple Row, Bristol Road, near Belgrave Middleway Stephenson Place, on the New Street ramp, and Kings Parade in Dale End, Birmingham Live reports. Deanaposs blue collar parents -  dad was painter and decorator and mum a machinist - were less than thrilled when he decided to ditch his A Levels to work full-time at the Golden Arches.  But he worked his way up from McDonaldaposs crew member to director level. In  he was appointed Head of Franchising UK, helping franchise owners run and manage their restaurant more effectively. In , he resigned as a McDonaldaposs employee to buy his own restaurants as a franchisee. Dean said: I first bought two - Stephenson Place and Dale End. A year later I took on Cherry Street, followed by Bristol Road. All the McDonaldaposs in Birmingham are franchisee owned. Dean said: When I started only around  to  per cent of UK McDonaldaposs restaurants were franchises - that is owned by independent business owners like me. It was not the UK model then. Now around  per cent of McDonalds restaurants in the UK are franchises. It has grown hugely. With a turnover of more than £.million, according to public accounts published for the year ending December , , he is certainly doing something right. Dean put his success down to hard work, graft and a bit of luck along the way. He said: If you put your heart and soul into the work, the opportunities are there. So what are his multi-million pound secrets   What were you doing before you started at McDonaldaposs  I was studying Physics,  Maths and Electronics at Leicester College. I wanted to be an electrical engineer and planned to go to university - I would have been the first in my family to go. I got a part-time job at my local McDonaldaposs in Leicester to help pay for a canoeing holiday.  When I came back from the holiday, I continued to work at McDonaldaposs and I ended up working more and more hours. I was practically a full-time employee before I knew it. I guess my lightbulb moment came after I ed from my holiday. I remember sitting in class at college, putting my hand up to ask to be excused to go to the toilet and being told I couldnapost and that I should have gone on a break. I threw my toys out of the pram, walked out and never went back. My parents were very disappointed,  I wasnapost going to university. Obviously they donapost feel that way now.  What I loved about the job - which is still true today - was it was all about teamwork and camaraderie. I’m a very shy person in general but after a few weeks I found my feet and within a few months,  I was running the kitchen with  staff. How do you progress from crew member   The management set-up back then was quite dferent. By the age of ,  I was running my own restaurant. I became Leicester area manager at . While going through the ranks I got a lot of training and business qualications at what we call hamburger university - an office in Sutton Coldfield. These are courses not externally recognised but when I go into organisations to talk about the franchisees, the stuff I’ve been taught are well-known business models.  My last few jobs as a McDonaldaposs employee were as director of operations and head of franchising in the UK. Why did you decide you wanted to be a franchisee  The higher up I got in the company, the further away I got from what I loved - interacting with staff. When I was training franchisees for the company, Iaposd give advice about what they could do to run a better McDonaldaposs and move the business forward. I wanted to implement these things myself. Now I have my own franchise business consultant  - the job I used to do -  who gives me a fresh pair of eyes and a good overview. Have your children any plans to follow your career path  They are very proud and it is a family business - my we is the bookkeeper. I have three children, Heidi, Finlay and Luke. Finlay has a natural affinity with business and wants to study that at university.  Luke and Heidi love maths. She is studying maths at St Andrews, where Kate Middleton and Prince William met. Apparently an Indian princess is studying there now! How do you become a franchisee and how much money do you need  You need an initial outlay of unencumbered cash of £,. And be accepted for an application programme. The selection process is quite intense. There is an extensive application process. Then there is a nine-month training period after that. Whataposs the best thing about being a franchisee  Seeing people progress. All my managers worked from crew up. I think it would be frustrating to work somewhere where there were no ways to progress - absolutely the opportunities are there in McDonaldapossyou want them.  For example one employee Cha who was on our apprenticeship programme started as crew in October  and was promoted to sht manager within four years. aposYou need an initial outlay of unencumbered cash of £, to own a franchiseapos You have to work very hard and put your heart and soul into it. There are other employees who donapost want to go up the ranks - which is fine. They just want a flexible job - and some cash to let them focus on other interests, whether that be sport or the arts. What changes have you seen since you started  When I started we didn’t sell breakfast - shocking when you consider how popular it is.   On the back of customer demand we have increased the breakfast time from .am to am so people can have a lie-in.  I remember the film Falling Down, when Michael Douglas is told he is a few minutes too late for the breakfast menu at a fast food restaurant and explodes. We donapost want people to feel like that! Also back when we started, it was just filter coffee. The only chicken we sold was nuggets. Describe your average day Every morning I get up at  and drive to Birmingham. Iaposm usually at the Dale End branch by .am. Iaposll get the business managers for the four stores together for a couple of hours.  Then they go back to their teams and have similar meetings with their teams. The rest of the day is spent catching up on emails. Every day starts with a meeting of some description - so it could be a team meeting. It could be a franchisee meeting, so we get together as franchisees and the community as well I currently have seven business managers working for me. title: plain looking tiny terrace house
story: NewsPlain-looking tiny terrace house on sale for £, hides incredible back gardenThe house, called Glenrosa, is situated on the Ceredigion coastline in the village of Borth, Wales - a short walk to the shops, pubs and restaurantsShareCommentsByJoanne Ridout:,  FEB NewsThe tiny terrace thats actually a six-bedroom family home with a beach for its back garden in Borth, Wales " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA terrace house with a magnicent sea and beach view is looking for a new owner. From the outside, the home looks like a standard terrace house - although it certainly stands out with its bright orange finish and baby blue doors and windows. But hiding behind its tiny facade is a six-bedroom family home and a rear that leads to a pebbled beach. The house, called Glenrosa, is situated on the Ceredigion coastline in the village of Borth, Wales - a short walk to the shops, pubs and restaurants. The view of Borth Beach and the Cardigan Bay coastline beyond makes the patio a great place for summer al fresco dining. Inside the home are three floors, with the extra floor created by utilising the loft space. Much of the interior of this home is designed with the seaside in mind. There are the whitewashed boardwalk style tiles in the shower room, the mini surfboards and le buoys on the bedrooms walls and sea landscape artwork. The ground floor offers a cosy living room that looks out to the street. There is an exposed brick fireplace with a log burner and stripped wood flooring. The room next to this is the dining room that can sit eight people in front of the exposed stone chimney fireplace. Also on the ground floor is the kitchen which leads to the back garden and offers sweeping views of the beach and sea. Imagine cooking Sunday lunch with the sound of the waves wafting in. The first floor room at the back of the house is the room with the best sea view. Originally built as a bedroom, the current owners have turned this into a lounge. They have added a large picture window that juts out so people can sit right by the window and watch the sea for hours. The master suite is on the same floor. It is not the largest room in the house, but it has a sublime view of the beach. There could be potential for a new owner to maximise the sea views from the pillow by adding in a Juliet balcony.

Reshawn Davis is set to be deported back to his homeland on Tuesday but says he is terried because he hasnapost been back to the Caribbean island since he was a child. The -year-old, who lives with his British we and six-month-old daughter in northwest London, was detained last Friday because of a robbery conviction a decade ago. He served two months in prison and has not been convicted of any crime since. Mr Davis is one of around  Jamaican nationals who are all set to be deported on the same flight. It will be the second charter flight to travel to Jamaica since the Windrush scandal two years ago.  Speaking from Colnbrook removal centre in Middlesex, Mr Davis, who has no family or friends in Jamaica, told The Independent:“I’m so stressed out. I can’t even explain how I feel. I made one mistake in le, and it feels like I tried to kill the Queen.“I look at my daughter’s pictures now every night before I go to bed. Since she was born I never had never spent a night without her until I was locked in here. I still reach for her when I wake up. I’m not one of those to leave my we to do it by herself. I want to be there for them both. Mr Davis believes he will be targeted by Jamaican residents when he reaches the country, which he hasnapost been to in  years. His we, Tonique Kerr, , said she would need financial help from the governmenther husband was to be deported. The scheduled charter flight which Mr Davis is due to be on has come under heavy criticism in recent weeks. There have been calls to delay the flight until a review into the lessons learnt from the Windrush scandal was published and its recommendations implemented.

British citizens could see changes to healthcare, driving permits and border control being made as a result - as well as ato the blue British passport, Gloucestershire Live reports. Immigration Minister Brandon Lewis has confirmed the current maroon covers are due to turn blue now that the UK is no longer a part of the European Union. The new passport is due to have up-to-date security features and technologies to protect against fraud and forgery - but the pages will be plastic instead of paper, making it more dficult to alter. They are due to be phased in over  andyou renew your passport in the next few months you could receive it in either colour.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailResidents are being evacuated from their homes and battle to secure properties from flooding, as Storm Ciara hammers the country with mph winds, heavy rain and huge waves. More than  flood warnings and alerts had been issued across the UK as of Sunday afternoon as homes and businesses were in danger of being inundated by swollen streams. Firefighters rescued a person who was trapped inside a car in a flooded street in Blackpool. The weather was so bad that the Queen did not attend church in Sandringham as a precaution due to high winds in the area. The haunting sounds of flood sirens redolent of air raids filled the streets this morning. Eerie footage posted to social media shows the market town of Hebden Bridge, in West Yorkshire, at dawn with sirens wailing as the entire country was covered by amber or yellow severe weather warnings. John McMahon, who captured video as the sirens went off in Hebden Bridge, told : This is only the second time in . years Iaposve lived here [that Iaposve heard the sirens]. Itaposs obviously an eerie sound to wake to. For a horrid moment you get a glimpse of the fear felt by people facing genuine catastrophesworldwide. Hopefully we wonapost be in that bracket here. Just trying to work out how we can help our neighbours. Weather warnings have been issued across the country for Sunday amid forecasts of very strong winds and the risk of flooding. A red aposdanger to leapos warning has flagged the River Nidd at Pateley Bridge and Bewerley in north Yorkshire as the river over-tops flood defences.The river level is forecast to peak at .m at around pm. Emergency services are taking action. Meanwhile, an aircraft hangeraposs roof was damaged in the wind at Duxford airfield causing the closure of the M motorway between junction  and junction  amid fears it could blow onto the busy road. The Humber Bridge, which connects East Riding of Yorkshire with North Lincolnshire, is closed to all traffic and pedestrians for only the second time in its history. And roads have been described as an aposobstacle courseapos with wheelie bins, recycling bins and trees blown into the paths of vehicles.Devon County Council Stuart Hughes said aposreports are coming in nowapos from people living along the south Devon coast encountering large objects misplaced by the winds. Hundreds of homes have been hit by a power cut with more than  homes across Devon and Cornwall experiencing a blackout. People travelling by train face nightmare journeys. London Euston rail station is evacuating its premises due to overcrowding, as journeys are cancelled, delayed or erted. Residents in Blackpool are being evacuated today after their homes were flooded. An emergency centre has been set up for those affected and is being run by volunteers. Incredibly, the force of the gusts of wind is causing the Big Wheel on Blackpoolaposs Central Peer to rotate on its own. PO Ferries has suspended its service from Dover to Calais due to strong winds. The company wrote on its Twitter: Due to strong winds, all the services of the port of Dover are currently suspended. We are sorry for the inconvenience and thank you for your understanding.The Dartford Crossing between Kent and Essex was closed. In some parts of the country a aposmajor incidentapos has been declared by fire and rescue services such as in Lancashire due to the high number of accident reports sparked by the storm. The Lancashire Fire and Rescue service has warned people not to travel unless absolutely necessary. With the force of the winds dislodging parts of building and sending debris flying, there are reports of people being injured.  Three people were hurt after the storm caused part of a pub roof to collapse in St John, Perth, on Saturday night. The chimney breast of a neighbouring building fell through the pubaposs roof causing it to cave in and dislodge the top of the pub building.  Emergency service said three people were passed into the care of the ambulance service. A missing surfer has been found in Rye Bay, Bexhill, following a search in a Coastguard helicopter. The surfer was reported missing off Hastings after he was spotted in hazardous seas off the Sussex coast.Police, three Coastguard teams, a helicopter and leboat were all involved in the search.Meanwhile, dozens of domestic and international flights have been cancelled, while rail companies in England, Scotland and Wales have urged passengers not to travel and say they will operate reduced timetables and speed restrictions on Sunday. A trampoline was blown onto the line at Chelsfield in Kent, causing severe disruption. The firms which have issued do not travel warnings are Gatwick Express, Grand Central, Great Northern, Hull Trains, LNER, Northern, Southeastern, Southern, Thameslink and TransPennine Express.  The other affected lines are: Avanti West Coast, cc, Chiltern Railways, CrossCountry, East Midlands Railway, Great Western Railway, Greater Anglia, Heathrow Express, Hull Trains, Island Line, London Northwestern Railway, London Overground, Merseyrail, Northern, ScotRail, South Western Railway, Stansted Express, TfL Rail, Transport for Wales and West Midlands Railway. Strong winds have the potential to damage overhead electrical wires and tracks due to debris or falling trees. Disruption could continue into Monday morning as repair work may be hampered by the conditions.  Heathrow Airport said it had agreed with its airline partners to consolidate Sundayaposs flight schedule in a bid to minimise the number of cancelled flights. British Airways said it was offering re-booking options for customers on domestic and European flights flying to and from Heathrow, Gatwick and London City on Sunday. Forecasters have warned flying debris could lead to injuries or endanger lives.  Officials also warned of possible damage to buildings and the chance of power cuts. The Met Office has an amber warning for wind in place for much of England and Wales from am until pm, while an amber warning for rain applies to parts of Scotland. Yellow weather warnings cover the whole UK with the heaviest rain expected over high ground, where -mm is expected widely with as much as mm in a few locations. title: hundreds people ski resort tested
story: NewsHundreds of people at ski resort tested for Coronavirus after Brit child, , diagnosedDozens of people who came into contact with a British child suffering from coronavirus have been tested for the disease in the ski resort of Contamines-Montjoie, in FranceShareCommentsByAlexandra WilliamsMatthew Dresch:,  FEB NewsThe test results are expected this evening " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHundreds of people who came into contact with the British child infected with Coronavirus in the French Alps have been tested for the deadly virus. Worried families, wearing facemasks, gathered at a medical centre adjoining the childaposs school in Les Contamines awaiting the results, which are due this evening. Officials have closed the -pupil primary school for lessons this week in the small ski resort, an hour from Geneva. The nine-year-old son of British couple Bob and Catriona Saynor, who moved to the Alps three years ago, is in hospital in France after being airlted from the resort on Friday afternoon. The local ambulance service estimated  people had been tested by Sunday afternoon. Health Minister Agnès Buzyn, speaking at a hastily arranged press conference in Les Contamines, said: “We have prioritised the children who have been in the most contact with the affected child, then the children who have symptoms and finally those who are less at risk because their contact has been reduced. “The situation is changing, our decision will depend on whether we have positive results in the evening.” Environmental consultant Mr Saynor, , has also been diagnosed with the deadly virus along with three other Britons from another family who were staying in the Saynor’s six-bedroom ski chalet. Mr Saynor’s two other children and four other Britons from the other family are in isolation in French hospitals as a precaution. A second school in nearby Saint-Gervais, which has  pupils and was attended by the Saynor’s son for one day last week, will also be shut this week. The mayor, Jean-Marc Peillex, advised against panic. He said: “We must not panic an entire population. We want to put into perspective the risk of contamination - the young Briton did not rub shoulders with a whole school but he rubbed shoulders with five students for half a day.” The Les Contamines Ski Club, where the child is a member, cancelled training on Sunday. One mother, whose child is friends with the British boy, was taking him to be tested. She said: “It’s scary. My son has had five days of high fever. Is it ‘flu  Is it something   We don’t know. I think it’s more contagious than they want to say.” Didier Mollard, a father of a child at the Les Contamines school, said: “We are taking their temperature twice a day and are watching them closely. We are worried  per cent for sure. “ Émilie Bétourné, a mother whose son attends the school, said: “My son is in the class of the brother of the child who is infected. “I am not panicking for the moment. I am waiting instruction from the doctors. We’ll listen to what they say and observe the health of our children. School is closed for the week.” Les Contamines village was eerily quiet on Sunday. The resort should usually be bustling with the start of the Paris half-term.  Local Sophie Lanier said: “It shouldn’t be this quiet in the resort. I think a lot of businesses are going to be worried that people won’t risk coming. It’s sad.” Skiers buying lt passes early Sunday morning also expressed their concerns. Joseph Dubois, , who was skiing with his we, said: “It’s a small ski station and we are a bit worried. We don’t know where the family went and who is now infected. It is a concern for certain.” Another skier, Laurent Guy, from Paris, said: “I have been coming here for a long time to this resort and I feel sorryit is going to be hit hard financially. It is a worry, of course, but we’re staying.” Annick Roger, director of the tourist board, said: Weaposve had a lot of calls.

title: a breather for united is just what the doctor ordered at tannadice
story: Saturday’s defeat for Dundee United showed the players need a bit of a breather – luckily for them they’ve got one this weekend.United fans would probably want a match to go to on Saturday but a rest weekend is just what the doctor ordered for Robbie Neilson and his men.What they’ve done this season already is a massive achievement and the day was always coming closer that they’d be punished for an off-day.That happened against Arbroath at Tannadice .There had been warning signs from the Red Lichties on their previous matches there – a - draw in the Challenge Cup and then leading - going into stoppage time before losing - in the league.Their gameplan obviously was effective and they stuck with it to good effect this time around.The dference on Saturday was United didn’t have enough about them to get a result.For me, that’s most likely a sign of fatigue, and possibly a wee bit of complacency.It’s really dficult to avoid the latter, particularly when suffering from tiredness.There’s also the build up of injuries.Nicky Clark is out for the rest of the season. His replacement Osman Sow was stretchered off on Saturday. Unfortunately, it sounds like he’ll sit out the rest of the campaign as well.But it’s a sign of the quality they have in their squad that Clark and Sow can be missing and you still have a striker of the calibre of Lawrence Shankland to lead the line. vw, px"  Sow being out leaves a great chance for youngsters like Declan Glass and Chris Mochrie to show what they can do in the No  position.It’s unfortanute for people to get injured but also a great chance for some of United’s youngsters to impress.On top of Sow’s injury, Paul McMullan, Louis Appere and Calum Butcher have been carrying injuries recently, too.This week is an ideal time to give the players a bit of a break and recharge the batteries for the run-in.The Tangerines want to get that title wrapped up as soon as possible but this breather couldn’t have been better timed.Once again, other teams weren’t really able to make up any ground on the runaway leaders – Inverness clawed one point back at home to Alloa.United are the only team that have managed any sort of consistency this season – a wee break is just what they need to get going again.

title: boxing fanatic gary todd describes brushes with the biggest stars in the sport since move from st marys to sydney

that his thick Dundonian accent does present a bit of a challenge at times, saying: #I do get some comments on it. title: dundee 2 0 partick hemmings double earns dark blues first win of 2020 with dominant display
story: Dundee finally picked up their first victory of  with a dominant - victory over bottom club Partick Thistle at Dens Park.Two first-half Kane Hemming goals did the damage for the Dark Blues as they moved back into the play-off places with a first three points since beating the Jags at Firhill on December .Dens boss James McPake made three changes after Cammy Kerr and Jordan McGhee underwent surgery during the week.That saw Josh Meekings come in to join Christophe Berra and Jordon Forster in a back three while Paul McGowan ed to partner Kane Hemmings up front and Christie Elliott made his first start.Andrew Nelson was on the bench after recovering from surgery himself alongside new signing Tom Field.The home side made a positive start and got the all-important breakthrough on  minutes.It stemmed from Meekings launching a throw into the Partick box and earning a corner. Declan McDaid lofted the kick into the box for Forster to steam in and head goalwards, only to see striker Hemmings knock it in on the line.Minutes later Dario Zanatta flashed a low shot wide of Conor Hazard#s post before Hemmings got his second of the afternoon on  minutes.Shaun Byrne#s long punt up top was miscontrolled and McGowan was all over the mistake. He played in his strike partner, who brushed off the Partick defence to fire past Scott Fox.Partick came out with more le about them in the second half with Zanatta a threat but Dundee were still creating chances and went close six minutes after the restart.First, McDaid saw a low cross kicked away by goalkeeper Fox before Ross Callachan was played in but could only hit the keeper with his effort from inside the area.On the hour, Christie broke forward but took the wrong option in choosing to shoot rather than pass before Fox again beat out a dangerous McDaid cross on  minutes.On  minutes, Dundee lost Callachan as he was stretchered off injured with Nelson replacing him.With six minutes to go, Brian Graham looked to have the chance to give the Jags a leline but he handled when controlling and the chance was gone.In the closing stages the Dark Blues were happy to see the game out as they moved back to fourth spot, three points behind second-placed Inverness.Dundee: Hazard, Forster, Meekings , Berra, McDaid, Christie, Byrne , McGowan, Dorrans, Callachan , Hemmings .Subs not used: Hamilton, Field, Cameron, Strachan.Partick: Fox, Penrice, O#Ware , Brownlie, Cardle , Bannigan, Graham, Cole, Zanatta, Barjonas , O#Connor .Subs not used: Sneddon, Robson, Austin.Attendance: ,

title: exclusive dundee city council worker sacked over email tampering claims
story: A high-profile Dundee City Council education officer has been sacked over claims he sent a ‘falsied email’ during the tendering process for a £, local authority contract.Kenny Christie, education support officer for arts and culture with the council, was hauled in front of council chiefs earlier this month over claims he interfered in the tendering process to provide sound technology for Dundee Schools Musical Theatrefor three shows last summer.Mr Christie, who worked for the council for the past  years, has strenuously denied the allegations and has confirmed he will be appealing against the decision.He was previously director with DSMT but has since left the company, which is funded by the council.The allegations centre on Blue Parrot Production and Events, based in Edinburgh.It is understood Blue Parrot missed the tender deadline for the DSMT contract and, when an email from the company was forwarded to the tender team, the date had been tampered with to make it look like it had been submitted on time.But Mr Christie has denied all links to the scandal and said: “I received a letter from Dundee City Council today, January .“I can confirm that I am not currently working for Dundee City Council in any capacity.“I have been removed from my post.“The council has accused me of deliberately forwarding a falsied email. There is no suggestion that I personally falsied this email.“The suggestion is that I forwarded the email after it had been falsied by someone .“I refute the allegations made against me and I can confirm I will be appealing against my removal from my post.Mr Christie also said he felt that the penalty seemed to be “disproportionate” to the accusations made against him.“No other allegations have been made against me,” he said.“I have worked in my current role for  years and have had an association with the council for  years.“I continue to have a huge respect for my council colleagues, council officers and elected members.“This is a very unfortunate time for me and I will need to take time to look at things moving forward.“I don’t wish to say anything further at this stage but will be making my intentions clear in due course.”Blue Parrot had provided sound equipment for DSMT for previous shows.DSMT producer and manager Lina Waghorn said: “I am shocked and saddened that Kenny Christie is no longer working with the council.“He was a great asset to DSMT and an inspirational teacher.”It’s understood students at DSMT were informed on Sunday January  that Mr Christie was “moving on to new projects”.It was made clear to students he was not ing and that Kris Mordente, a St John’s Academy teacher, would be taking over director permanently.A source at DSMT said: “It’s just a bit strange that he’s gone. Kenny was DSMT and DSMT was Kenny. I don’t think anyone knows how we’re going to operate without him.“He had been growing distant for a while, we have only seen him three times since August and at one point Lina mentioned bringing in an assistant director.“It’s not something we’d expect, I think everyone here including Lina would be reluctant to let him go.”A Blue Parrot spokesman said the company was not awarded the DSMT contract because “strictly speaking, we did not meet the deadline.”A Dundee City Council spokesman said: “We do not comment on inidual personnel matters.”Kenny Christie has been described as one of the most “sought-after” musical theatre directors in the country.He has worked with DSMT for over  years, producing several musicals like Les Miserables and Annie.His directing career began at the age of , producing a one-act play as part of the SCDA drama festival.In , Mr Christie became the world record holder for the fastest theatrical production, taking one piece from book to stage in just . hours.He has also taught and organised dance workshops ,in Dundee and Perth, and has worked with Dundee City Council to organise dance activities for school pupils.Mr Christie has also held the title of chairman of the Heads of Instrumental Teaching Scotland, as well as being the first Youth Adviser for Scotland for the National Operatic and Dramatic Association.Kenny Christie’s sacking comes in the wake of a separate fraud scandal that has rocked Dundee City Council in the past year.In October, the council’s head of construction Mark Ross quit in the midst of an investigation into claims he was treated to a golfing trip on the Spanish coast by bosses of a firm awarded an £ million local authority contract.The £.m deal to provide heat and smoke and carbon monoxide detectors was awarded to Edmundson Electrical without going out to tender.The trip to Spain took place weeks after the contract was awarded and included Mr Ross, a senior Edmundson staff member, another council employee and representatives of two other firms.It was later revealed that the second council employee was Kenny Muir, who also worked in the council’s construction department.He was sacked from his role earlier this month.Mr Muir is the fourth senior employee to leave construction services since September, following the resignations of Mr Ross and electrical supervisor Iain Gardyne, who is accused of selling thousands of pounds’ worth of council smoke alarms online.

title: field set to make bow against jags
story: Left-back Tom Field is set to be thrust straight into the Dundee starting line-up this weekend.The -year-old joined the Dark Blues late last Friday after news of first-choice Jordan Marshall’s injury came back worse than first feared.Scan results on the thigh injury Marshall picked up in training arrived around lunchtime on the day of the transfer deadline.That forced manager James McPake into swt action to add cover in the shape of Field, who had left boyhood club Brentford earlier that day.With the late arrival, last weekend’s clash at Greenock Morton came too soon to make his debut with Jordan McGhee playing in the unfamiliar role on the left of defence.After meeting his new team-mates and training all week, Field is now likely to make his bow in dark blue against Partick Thistle on Saturday.To give him some match action, Field took part in a bounce game at Stirling Albion on Tuesday in which Andrew Nelson and Paul McGowan also featured after missing out at Cappielow through injury.Nelson, who scored in the match, has been out since the turn of the year after surgery to fix a broken hand.After seeing Christophe Berra and Christie Elliott make their debuts at Morton with Conor Hazard making a second bow after ing on loan, Field is likely to make his first outing against the Jags.Manager James McPake said: “Tom Field trained this week.“Jordan Marshall being out is disappointing because he’s been excellent.“He will miss eight weeks at least, maybe .“It’s a problem deep in the thigh muscle so it’s dficult to know when it has healed.“Jordan is an explosive player so we have to make sure he is right with that one.”Berra, meanwhile, made his first appearance in over a month last weekend and manager James was pleased with his start to le at the club.He added: “Christophe was good. At the end, he admitted he was tired, it was his first  minutes in six weeks so, for that, he was really good.“Jordon Forster was really good beside him and the full-backs did well.“It’s not easy when balls come into your box constantly but I thought they held their own.”

story: The owner of a family-run paint and wallpaper shop has said its closure after  years will mark the “end of an era”.The director of Lawrence Milne Decorators, Kevin Milne, has announced the store at the Berryden Retail Park in Aberdeen will be closing down later this month.He said the outlet, which has operated in a iety of locations, will shut due to “rising costs and tough trading conditions in the retail market”.Kevin added: “Over the last four or five years, it’s just became harder, especially with there being more competition now and more competition online as well.”But Mr Milne has stressed that the shop in Ellon and the painting and decorating side of the business will not be affected.He said: “The painting and decorating side is the main part of the business, and hasn’t been affected by this.”

title: new count reveals one in five union street shops lying empty1
story: One in five shops on Aberdeen#s Union Street are currently empty.Of the  retail units,  are unoccupied with firms shutting up shop or moving on where.The majority of the empty units are in the west end of Union Street, with  units counted between the Holburn Junction and Bon Accord Street.Of the total number of units, more than % are either a betting, vape or charity shop.Restaurants, bars, and takeaways account for % of the units on the street.One of the prominent vacant sites, the former Waterstones bookstore, has already attracted interest from discount retailer Poundland, which applied for a business warrant to internally fit out the site, which has lain vacant since the booksellers moved to the Bon Accord Centre in May .Other shops planned for Union Street include a Taco Bell and a Tesco, both set to open later this year.In August last year, The Esslemont restaurant and Mac’s Pizzeria opened in the former Esslemont and Macintosh department store, which shut in . The site was then occupied by Jamie’s Italian, which opened in February , before closing down in .Dustin Macdonald, chairman of the Aberdeen City Centre Community Council, said: “It’s disappointing to see so many units lying empty on Union Street but it becoming increasingly dficult for business owners who are up against online shopping.“There are a lot of empty units, particularly on the upper floors of Union Street, and it would be great to see that space being used.“But it is a widespread problem because businesses are up against online shopping nowadays. I do think there is an onus on business owners to try to make their building more appealing to customers.“There are grants available for business ownersthey wish to have the front of their stores done up, and I would encourage them to do so.”Under the city centre masterplan, a blueprint approved by the local authority in June , a number of objectives were set out to regenerate the city over the years to come, while conserving its heritage.Phase one of its planned projects are currently underway, which includes the rejuvenation of Aberdeen Art Gallery, which opened in November, and the pedestrianisation of Broad Street, which was finished at the start of August .Other schemes include installing suspended street signs in areas across the city centre and banning traffic on Langstane Place, Justice Mill Lane and Windmill Brae from pm to am.Phase two of the scheme is planned for years four to seven of the project and includes ersying employment space as well as developing skills and training in the services sector.The Queen Street initiative, which forms part of phase two, also hopes to deliver more than  new homes and incorporate a civic hub.In , a Union Street Conservation Area Regeneration Scheme , was launched. The five-year initiative aims to “restore the majesty” of Aberdeen’s main street, and is a £. million grant fund which is available to owners of eligible buildings to undertake high quality repairs, restoration and the refurbishment of buildings.Since its inception, it has been used to refurbish a former jewellers into a hot dog restaurant.Real Hot Dogs at  Union Street opened in August  after making use of the grant to clean up the shop front, however it closed in January last year.The scheme is currently planned to run until .Adrian Watson, chief executive of business body Aberdeen Inspired, said: “Union Street as a high street is changing and this is necessary, in a challenge that is not felt in Aberdeen alone, but across the country.“We need to think dferently about the experience we offer and of course there are still challenges here as we make this transition. Our efforts to continue revitalising Union Street are ongoing and enhancing the experience for those living and working in the city is an integral part of what we do as an organisation as we aim to drive footfall in the city centre.”Aberdeen City Council is taking an active approach to improve the city centre and has served notices on businesses deemed to “negatively impact the amenity of the area.”The owner of one business, Inspirations on Union Street which is vacant, was asked to make a string of repairs due to its condition bringing “signicant disamenity” to the area.An appeal was lodged with the Scottish Government last year which was rejected this month.Councillor Marie Boulton, the council’s lead on the city centre masterplan, said: “Union Street remains very much the heart of Aberdeen. The council is working with Historic Environment Scotland to conserve the fabric of its most important buildings by offering grants to owners.“CARS also aims to stimulate the economy by encouraging occupancy of vacant commercial units and upper floors for residential use. The council is continuing to invest in our heritage as well as events that showcase our unique streetscape.”

title: science matters the future for organ donation
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowPresently around , people in the UK are waiting for organ transplantation. All have end-stage organ failure, be it kidney, liver, lung or heart, and require a le-saving transplant.Organs for transplant usually come from bodies of people who agreed to donate before death. But as this does not produce enough organs, both Scotland and England plan to bring in an #opt out# system, meaning that on death a person#s agreement to organ donation is assumed unless they had actively opted out.Live donation is an alternative to awaiting a cadaveric organ. As people can live happily with one kidney or half a liver, family members or altruistic iniduals sometimes offer to donate these organs. Since matching donor and recipient tissue-type, however, is generally required these donations are not always acceptable.Now groups of tissue-type incompatible donor recipient pairs are getting together to mix and match, producing duos who are tissue-type-compatible. So let#s say Annie is rejected as a kidney donor for her sister Jean for incompatibility reasons, and similarly, Arthur is rejected as kidney donor for Jim. But pairing donor Annie with recipient Jim and Arthur with Jean could lead to two successful transplants. A recent report from the US describes the first ever bi-organ exchange involving a liver-kidney swap * .In this specic case a daughter wished to donate a kidney to her mother with renal failure but was rejected because she might later develop the same kidney problem. So she offered half of her liver in exchange for a kidney for her mother. Another donor was eventually identied who wanted to donate half her liver to her sister with liver failure but was rejected because her liver was too small. But she was cleared for kidney donation. So on the day of the swap four operations took place and two needy people received le-giving new organs.Although not presently being considered in the UK, with the ethical issues sorted, this multi-swap procedure opens the way for extended chains of donors and many more lives saved.*Torres et al Am J transplant. :-.

title: eco group in mid argyll helps flush away poverty
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowArdrishaig Church Eco Group is helping provide people with access to a safe loo, clean water and hygiene education as it raises funds for the Toilet Twinning charity.One in three people worldwide currently do not have somewhere safe, private or hygienic to go to the toilet, with many having to go out into fields and areas of bushland.As a result, people are deprived of the dignity of having access to a proper toilet, leading to health problems, often causing them to be unable to work or attend school.Lack of access to clean water and proper sanitation traps people in poverty. Their health suffers and the prospect of developing economically remains out of reach. For women and young girls, the consequences can be even worse, with many being attacked and raped when they use outdoor spaces. Girls are also removed from school when they reach puberty because of the lack of safe facilities.Through Toilet Twinning, it costs £ to build a toilet for an inidual family and £ to provide a block of toilets for a school or a displaced peoples camp.To raise vital funds, the group will host a coffee morning at Ardrishaig Parish Church Hall on Saturday January  and invites everyone to go along as it #helps to change the world, one toilet at a time#.

title: letters to the editor january 17 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,in  The Argyllshire Advertiser ran a story entitled #Skate park pipe dream a reality for Lochgilphead#. Nearly three years later I fear the dream is still a long way from that reality.Mid Argyll Youth Development Servicescertainly seems to have ambitious plans for an indoor skate park and this is to be lauded, however a quick look online will show an apparent apathy with regard to moving forward with the project. A young man created the #Lochgilphead Skate Park Association# on Facebook in , yet a final post in  indicated how little the proposal had moved forward. If the project needs more money to actually get it built we need to know how much, so that appropriate funding can be sought.What is causing the project to take years to come to fruition The potential for help by the £ million Tarbert and Lochgilphead Regeneration Fund in  was dashed when councillors instead decided that improvements to road junctions, streets, a cycle track and indoor bowling were more important, and allocated a staggering £, to feasibility studies for these projects alone, this is before any work is actually done, you understand.That is a great deal of money for feasibility studies and design works.Let us be realistic # in nine long years the community has gone from the initial excited buzz about a skate park to finally managing to purchase a plot of land upon which to build it in early . From there it seems the project has not been able to move.In the meantime the youngsters who worked so hard to give momentum to the project appear to have given up hope and are now probably giving thought to employment prospects rather than having fun.It is a sad state of affairs.But rather than giving up hope, let us reignite this campaign for our children to have the dream of a skate park in Lochgilphead whilst they are still young enough to enjoy it.Nick MacIneskar, TayvallichSir,With regard to your story in last week#s Argyllshire Advertiser #Inveraray seawall in need of attention#, would it be possible to contact BEAR Scotland and ask themthey could also create an access point to the shore Possibly at the bus stop at Barn Brae. Thanks very much.Marion McIntosh, InveraraySir,I should like to make an appeal to all MPs, MSPs, councillors and all lawmakers that in  they make no new laws.At the beginning of this new decade they should improve the laws they already passed. I would even like for them to go further and reduce the number of laws that are in existence.Now please don’t get me wrong, I am not against all laws. What I fear is that instead of addressing the issues which are negative to iniduals and society, legislators believing that by extending what are regarded as crimes changes society for the better. Their belief is wrong.We know that parking on pavements is wrong #upskirting# is horrying smoking in a car in which they are children is unacceptable dropping litter is shameful driving through a red light is dangerous.What we need is the range of social and cultural influences that help us feel that we should behave in a positive way. In the s, s and s the majority of people regularly attended churches and religious organisations. In these environments people developed feelings of what was right and wrong. Positive behaviour was also developed by participating in the extensions of these organisations through activities in young mother groups women#s guilds, choirs, and religious celebrations. These helped develop positive moral compass in people.Equally, most children and young people went to youth organisations such as the Girl Guides, Scouts, the BBs, army and naval cadets. Even into the s local authorities ran youth clubs and had excellent people called #youth leaders#. No more. #We cannot afford them# is the call of the day. Without them the honourable behaviour of society will continue to deteriorate.So my plea to politicians is simple # stop making us all criminals by passing more and more laws and start supporting and encouraging agencies, groups and people who indirectly and directly instil in iniduals behaviour of which all can be proud.Finlay CraigCoveSir,There is all the hoo-ha at the moment over the lesser royals deciding its going to be a better le that beckons from opting out from royal duties # perhaps wanting a less stressful, more normal, le for themselves and their family as ordinary people away from the media hype and national newspapers.It was lovely, however, to see in the same week front page on the local paper a real regional award for a less well-known commoner.An MBE given for services to the local youth community, making this two great awards for Lochgilphead in recent years and showing that local strong ladies in Mid Argyll do have what it takes.Hard work and true Scottish grit and determination in their hearts for the area and community. More of the same meritorious awards for the ordinary people of Scotland please.Credit to all editors and staff for their outstanding journalism given over the years in all of Scotlands progressive, thriving local papers.Stephen Jones, Oban

We did not have the new kitchen then. The hotel has always cooked the turkeys for us but cooking big pots of potatoes and vegetables was quite a job with just the gas rings. Back then, we had ice-cream and jelly for dessert.#Jean added: #It was all good fun and we had loads of laughs.#Elma continued: #We used to have sales to raise money for the dinner.
